reviewText:
I sit here at my computer desk in the wee hours of the morning after just completing the first part of the Homeworld: Remastered games that were recently released on Steam, and as I type away I find it hard to come to the correct words for what I just experienced, so here’s me trying to sum it up for you with what to me is no longer a game, or a footnote on a sheet to check out and play sometime in the future without really ever getting to it, but an idea that was realised in it’s fullest potential and is now at the public’s door once again.
Let’s get one thing out the door right away, I never played the original Homeworld. I was too young at the time to really decide what I wanted to play, and what I did play was mostly Starcraft: Brood War (Still in my top games of all time) or rummage through the bucket of Lego in my corner.  So when the news that Homeworld was getting a remaster… I didn’t really celebrate at all and I certainly did not pre-order out the door like I do for way too many games.  Though as the ball kept turning and the time of it’s release drew nearer and nearer I grew infatuated with Homeworld, it’s lore and story that drew me instantly into it, and the sheer scale and effort being put into a game that was cracking on by now.  So this Monday, which is Monday the 2nd of March (I am writing this review on the 7th, in the early hours) I bought it as soon as I could, and here is the result.

Homeworld is now what I consider the best story told in gaming.
Or at least up there with the greats, of course.
The way it was told to me, and how it slowly started to show me this lore that spanned back millions of years in the games universe, the different races and characters I met along the way all felt amazing and diverse, each one beautifully voice acted and all done with space ships on a screen.  There’s no portraits, we aren’t given a face, it’s voices we go on in this experience, and holy hell it knocks it out of the park with that regard.
It’s game play (While frustrating at times) is brilliant fun to toy with, there’s nothing more satisfying then launching a full Missile Destroyer attack on the unsuspecting foe below as your attack bombers soar in to deal the final blow, it’s god damned addicting and the fun just comes from finding the ways to out manoeuvre your enemies in the slyest of ways.
And finally it’s the music, and how it complements each scene perfectly to the point I was left in awe at what was beset upon my eyes, to the point where this game brought me to tears with the myriad of feelings it produced.  Emotion is key with this tittle, and for the first time in a good long while I was feeling it while playing a game, the twinge of my heart as my favourite Frigate bit the dust, or the cut scenes I will not spoil.
Homeworld is an experience for everyone, RTS and non RTS fan alike need to play this game and make it through to the end for the most satisfying ending in gaming.  This game gets my rating of ‘Bury it with me so I can take it to hell’

reviewText:
I love Homeworld. I read about, and waited for the original. I managed to get into the original beta (I have the CD framed). I played this game for hours and days on end. I was depressed when it turned out that the remote turrets were op in mass, and a created nearly unbeatable playing strategy. I felt like a hero when I found a way to beat it. I endured many losses, and more victories playing friends online. I once managed to steal an entire enemy players capital ship fleet with my own fleet of salvage corvettes and a cloaking frigate. THIS, This was Homeworld. Strategy, intuitive interface, as may ships as your computer could handle, and ships that did what you told them.

This is not what Gearbox released. They didn't understand the game they were remastering, and because of this, they created an atrocity compare to the original. It is as if they tried to recreate the Mona Lisa using Crayons. They didn't get it. I was afraid this was going to happen when Team Pixel lost the bid for the THQ Bankruptcy. They got it, they understood what made this game so amazing. I was right to fear. GearBox didn't understand; they thought that they could just make it pretty, and as simple as possible. They didn't get that what made Homeworld great wasn't the beauty of the game (though it was spectacular visually), but rather the way everything functioned.

If you never played the original, you won't know what you are missing. You will probably enjoy the game just fine.  If you did, don't bother, this game will just make you sad. It will kill off part of your youth.

P.S. Most of the hours I have played were just trying to get the game to work on three monitors.

reviewText:
Be careful before you buy.

If you were expecting a complete port of the original homeworld with a graphical update then this is not the game you're looking for, save your money and play the classic version.

There's features in the remastered HW1 that aren't working as intended, Tactics and Formations are broken and are (apparently) not likely to be fixed. It is impossible for anyone who played HW1 to not notice that these things are broken and any claim that they're working as intended, or that it doesn't negatively effect gameplay is patently false.

Listen, I'm not a purist but the developers had to of known this wasn't working correctly. Why they couldn't have been up front with people and say that there were certain things they couldn't port and let us decide whether or not we wanted to make the trade offs for the better graphics? Probably because they now have my 30 dollars and don't really give a crap. That sort of dishonest buy-now-patch-later crap is what is ruining PC gaming.

The game is playable although buggy, and from what I am reading HW2 is working as intended, but not going to lie when I say that HW1 remaster is a let down.

reviewText:
Summary: This is the remake that Homeworld fans have been waiting for. The Homeworld Remastered Collection features everything included in Homeworld and Homeworld 2, with a modern UI and vastly improved graphics.

Pros:

Multiplayer thus far is working well.
AI is FAR more sophisticated and difficult than in the older games.
Campaign cinematics have been updated.
Sound design is greatly improved, with many of the old familiar effects redone.
Game setup options are greatly increased over the original.
Classic Homeworld complexity and gameplay.

Cons:

Menu lag persists, but developers seem to be patching often.
Multiplayer is still in beta, and can still crash.
Some minor graphical glitches at release.

Overal: Definitely reccomend. I gave this game/remake 9 out of 10.

reviewText:
*Note This is a work in progress review, it will change if devs address the major issues with a few of the mechanics.

Even though the graphics, audio and UI redesigns are good I cannot recommend this game right now. It seems like gearbox has broken gameplay mechanics entirely in the remaster of HW1 because of the porting of engine to HW2 engine. Here are just a few of the issues:


-The formations are wonky and don't work. You need formations to strike enemy ships effectively. In these games they just use their own flight patterns after they get close to enemy and don't stay in formation.
-Game is not using balistic system of the original and instead uses rng, so there are too much hard counters to everything. It is not physics based.
-Support frigates are useless unless you get them to follow around and make sure they are healing targets.
-Capturing mechanics broken, it is too easy.
-salvage corvettes easily capture enemy corvettes because evasion mechanics disabled(they are not part of the rng system)
-Salvage ships not showing their beam animation
-Why is queues limited to 2?
-Collision system is broke, stuff like resource collecters and other ship crash into astroids or other objects and then attempt to push through them instead of moving back.
-Some shortcuts do work but its inconsistent, like some keys open certain menus but don't close them when pressed again, while others close when pressed again. Its weird.

EDIT:

Seems I was wrong with some of the UI mechanics. You can highlight and then choose what ships to select, or you can double click a selected ship and it will highlight all similar ships nearby. You can also select military only ships to be highlighted.

This is a very good UI mechanic in the game, just wish they would explain in the tutorials.

reviewText:
I was (am) an owner of the original games, hw1, hw Cataclyism, hw where you play as the tuscan raiders & hw 2.  I love the games, and I was very happy when I heard about and purchased the re-released, updated version of HW1 & 2.

However good they are, they are not without their fault, these faults only exist in the remastered versions however.

The graphics are very pretty indeed, a lot of time has clearly gone into redoing it all, I would say that it's a bit of a system hog, I've got a very good, top of the range gaming laptop and the fps dips horrendously if everything is maxed during a firefight - however it's still in Beta and I've no problem dropping my settings a little, and I'll gladly update this review once the game is no longer in the beta stage.

Storyline hasn't changed, it could easily be made into a series or movie, that's how good it is.  Nor has the sound fx or music been amended, this isn't a bad thing as both capture the situations perfectly.  There are still a few bugs here, but again, it's Beta.

The single player campaigns are the same, 16 missions for each game, plus the beta multiplayer.  The whole game is still beta though really, lets not fool ourselves here.

In terms of gameplay the first is (was) more difficult and required more patience, finesse etc.  That feeling has gone and now the game feels somewhat dumbed down, the UI is simpler, easier, it's not something I approve of as previously in HW1 you were able to assign your ships different tactics, more power to engines or weapons at the cost of the other, or the middle ground.  On top of this you were also able to assign formations, these have gone, what remains is something that's an insult to previous games here.  I don't know why they didn't keep it because it brings in whole new dimensions, particulalry in multi player.  It is however the Beta and so perhaps they will re introduce them.  Whilst these things were only present in HW1, the sequal and the muiltiplayer would be vastly improved if included.  Yet are not, why Gearbox, WHY?

There are still balacing issues with the ships, for example in multiplayer you have the choice of either being Taiidan or Kushan from HW1, or Vagyr or Hiigarian from HW2.  There are pros and cons to each, but the latter 2 are more superior in the long run, and are easier for new players to get to grips with the game.  Whilst these ship balancing problems are by no means game breaking they are a little ridiculous.  For example the laser corvettes from the vagyr are specifically designed to destory frigates and capital ships, and they do this very well...the problem is that it's a little too well.  Whilst there are ships designed to destroy them, you can't help but feel there still many issues that need to be addressed.

The game may also crash if you click your mouse during the multplayer loading screen, post lobby.  I suppose that one is game breaking.  Just don't click and you'll be fine :)
I'm sure Gearbox will fix the issues as they have made numerous improvements so far.  It's merely a question of when, not if.

To summerise, this is still a fantasic game the graphics are ooohhh aaaaa" pretty

reviewText:
I love homeworld, and nothing has ever been close to the beauty and enjoyment of this game.  I always want to slow down fighting and watch in a thousand different angles of the fighters weaving in and out while capital ships turn broadside to unload their deadly payloads.

No space game has ever been remotely close to being like homeworld. Even sins was vastly different.  Something about homeworld is simply original and stunning.

The remastered version brings the UI of Homeworld 2 to Homeworld 1 which works. My only complaint is build and research menus can consume what feels like a third of the screen.  Beyond that the game runs so very fluid, like a interstellar ballet.

The combat chatter is excelent, though build reminders can become repetative if you are building fast constructing ships that cause the voice to repeatedly remind you that an interceptor is completed.

I love this game, I loved it then and I still love it now.

10/10

One does not simply recognize that this is already a 15 year old game without being told XD

After 15 years this game is still the best at what it does and it has certainly aged beautifully.

Why so much complaining?

My advice to those with issues, complaints or problems :

* Wait for bugfixes or the modding community to fix it, which they certainly will :D just be patient. You have to bear in mind that this game is already 15 years old and was just remastered, not remade.

* Play the Homeworld 2 Classic ( which what Ive been doing ) . I honestly think it is better than the remastered version ( looks aside ) because of all those great mods! Which are:

a. Complex mod

b. Homefront mod ( they have very awesome looking ships )

c. Complex Enhanced ( kinda like complex but without the ranks, energy and research points )

d. Tactical Fleet Simulator ( makes the game more fast paced and has cool new ships )

e. FreeSpace: Fleet Command

These mods make the classic better than the remastered and i could never again go back to playing vanilla homeworld because they just add so much more to the game

You can all download these mods in the workshop with just a single click.

I hope this helped! See you in the Homeworld everyone!

Because of its fair price and the 4 games that it contains i give it a score of:

9/10 Please start developing Homeworld 3!

( might be 10/10 in the future when they patch things up and some awesome mods gets released )

reviewText: After playing this game for a few hours and reliving the nostalgia of my childhood I'd have to say that the game definitely delivered. However! There are a few bugs or irritations (namely 2 during my playthrough) that should be prioritized for a fix above all else if I'm to call it the closest to perfect" remaster and that is to recalibrate the formations so that they actually have a meaning in the game. There have been so many instances (practically the whole game) where formations didn't decide the flow of battle. The units just scattered in combat and thus left a lot of undeserved casualties.\nThe second thing to fix is the AI for the harvesters. In the original you could send them out to do their business and wouldn't need to worry about them unless being attacked. But after finishing the first nebula mission and sending them to harvest the rest of the area

reviewText:
One does not simply recognize that this is already a 15 year old game without being told XD

After 15 years this game is still the best at what it does and it has certainly aged beautifully.

Why so much complaining?

My advice to those with issues, complaints or problems :

* Wait for bugfixes or the modding community to fix it, which they certainly will :D just be patient. You have to bear in mind that this game is already 15 years old and was just remastered, not remade.

* Play the Homeworld 2 Classic ( which what Ive been doing ) . I honestly think it is better than the remastered version ( looks aside ) because of all those great mods! Which are:

a. Complex mod

b. Homefront mod ( they have very awesome looking ships )

c. Complex Enhanced ( kinda like complex but without the ranks, energy and research points )

d. Tactical Fleet Simulator ( makes the game more fast paced and has cool new ships )

e. FreeSpace: Fleet Command

These mods make the classic better than the remastered and i could never again go back to playing vanilla homeworld because they just add so much more to the game

You can all download these mods in the workshop with just a single click.

I hope this helped! See you in the Homeworld everyone!

Because of its fair price and the 4 games that it contains i give it a score of:

9/10 Please start developing Homeworld 3!

( might be 10/10 in the future when they patch things up and some awesome mods gets released )

reviewText:
This collection is amazing. First about the collection itself, the collection has a whole bunch of content that at the time of writing I haven't even got to yet. Not only do they have the original homeworld 1 and 2, but also the re-mastered version which clearly had a lot of love put into them.

Now, I know some people will call this blasphemous, but I haven't played the original versions, and I'll give a review for each game in the collection. There may be changes in the originals and remasters like the UI and apparently some unit balancing issues? Again, the changes seem small and don't seem to impact the gameplay for the casual or moderate homeworld fan.
Anyway, onto the review, I'll go in order of Homeworld and Homeworld 2 had to be cut short due to me running out of characters. [grumble grumble]


Homeworld was an amazing experience to go through, and gave me a feeling a game hasn't given me in awhile. This is a sense of mystery and the feeling of being a small speck in the midst of outer space. An insignificant spec, just managing to survive. But as you go along, the largest foe opposing you who seem like an unstoppable force that will wipe you out in the blink of an eye. But you just bite at the small, weak appendages of this large creature until you (hopefully) become large enough to stand a chance.

But as the game goes along, and you realise you're hatred of this foe is not alone, you end up becoming stronger, as you gain more and more victories, and you become something greater than what you started, you don't feel weak against your foe, you end up feeling like you can just make it.

Now, for the gameplay of the game, the gameplay is very strategic, much more strategic than what I was expecting. You can't just throw your mighty battleships at the enemy and expect to win, because since you may of destroyed their first offensive, you're heavily crippled, and it just so happens that there are, admittedly smaller, but far scarier foes awaiting just outside the range of your sensors, and they are hungry. I find myself later in the game attempting to break off their fleet in chasing something small, but leading them where my ships lay, and I have the advantage by planning the whole thing in advance. Your experience might be different but I had a blast.

Now for some memorable moments from my playthrough of the game, some spoilers.

The first moment I can think of is the first attack on the foe (completely forgot their name, some federation). When we warp in, my battle relay guy(?) notifies me that the hostile fleet is right ahead. Here, I'm a bit scared ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ because I saw what they can do, and even though its weakened, they still have a substantial fleet. He gave the order to exterminate the fleet. At this moment of time, I still see that fleat as an unstoppable force, and they had battlecruisers and I didn't. Did I mention I was scared? Anyway, I mass produced these vehicle extraction units (forgot the name) which basically steals ships in hopes of capturing one of the ships. However, it turned out that I overestimated the foe (which is what I always do, it's better to overestimate and crush your foe with overwhelming force them to not be prepared for a superior force) and I ended up destroying most of their ships, except for one. I then got this evil grin on my face as this carrier was trying to escape from me, I ordered my ships to shoot out the engines, and I sent in the extractors. I ended up stealing their carrier as a trophy, a claim of I annihilated your force and now I'm using your ship against you" sort of fashion. That ship eventually became invaluable to the fleet
date: acting as a medical station for the smaller ships and as a transport bay for them as well. Protection from attack.\n\nThe second moment I'll share is this moment when you enter a nebula and there is deadly radiation flooding the area. You had to plan your moves carefully to not have your ship's be dissolved in the radiation (a bit unrealistic but it's a videogame so I'll let it slide) I'm moving through this cloud and I spot a minelayer. reviewText:
Of all the remaster's I have encountered this is the best one by far. Gearbox didn't want to reimagine the game or reinvent it, they got the old developers back together and remade the game in all its glory. Hell if you don't want to play the remastered versions you even get the old classic versions  that have been updated to work on modern OS's.

The new interface is a huge improvement and the game itself has been refined to work smoothly and painlessly. The multiplayer is still in beta but to be honest, if you buy this for the multiplayer you are going to be dissapointed, the core feature of the Homeworld series has always been about the story, the story of the Hiigarans.

This game isn't just a remaster, this is the revival of a series, and it is very clear the developers didn't just want to create something the fans would love, but something they would also love, this game is a love letter to the fans to say thanks for the support.

Also the mods are pretty great.

reviewText:
This is a remastered game from back in the day when RTS ruled the PC.

Back in the day i used to love this game, unlike its competitors at the time you aren't fighting on a 2d plane but in an actual 3d environment. Given this is a space game you actually get a tactical advantage from attacking enemy ships from the top of bottom, so it added literally another dimension to the RTS genre.

Another great feature of the game is you dont build a base, but maintained a fleet (think Battlestar Galactica), that fleet stays with you throughout the game. You have the mother ship that acts as production facility and when that is lost, its game over, all other ships can just be produced and captured. It adds a lot to the story.

And the story that was told is great, for those of you who have never played it, i wont spoil it, but the story itself is kind of standard, but because you are with traveling with your fleet, you feel more connected to the story!

And the best part is, that was how i remember it, and it all still holds true!! and now it looks great also.

So i do recommend this game if you are into RTS games or really atmospheric games!

reviewText:
One of the best games from the late 90's has been overhauled and finally been given the look that the game deserves. Not only has this game sent me back to my own youth but its also rekindled an unhealthy relationship with the game series that I spent most of my teens playing, mainly when I should have been doing my homework!

Homeworld Remastered beings homeworld 1 and homeworld 2 into today with vastly improved graphics and a remastered audio track. The look and feel of the game is very similar to homeworld 2 as both the remastered games use an upgraded version of the HW2 game engine but with upgrades to improve the look.
Neither game however have lost anything but only gained. Infact homeworld 1 now plays with the options you had in homeworld 2.

Homeworld 1 remastered even let you build in single units rather than small groups of fighters as you do in 2.

The campaigns are better than ever with the storyline not changed, the increasingly difficult missions of HW1 gets transfered over in homeworld remastered nicely.
The player vs CPU, or skirmish mode has a stange feel to it, but has been upgraded to feature some new modes including tasks such as harvest x resources for a bonus; and crates. However the best feature allows you to pit HW1 factions against HW2. Although in BETA at the time of writing this review, the multiplayer mode shows some promise.

I do feel that the pitting of sides from HW1 and HW2 against eachother is a nice feature, it does need some ironing out. So far the HW2 sides seem to have the edge on the HW1 sides. It would be nice to see some new features other than game modes. Maybe some more maps, special units for skirmish, maybe even a turanic raiders or kadeshi faction to play in skirmish/multiplayer.

Not only do you get the remastered games, the classic versions are also here too for that ultimate look back.

I do have to admit though, it was nice to play the entire game in a few days and it took me back a fair few years. I can highly recommend. If you loved the classic games back in the day, then remastered is for you.

reviewText:
I think they did a good job on this re-master. I have all of these games and the missing cataclysm game. I bought this off the shelf originally before it became GOTY in 1999. I played this until the game disk broke in a move 5 years ago. It’s my all-time favorite game.  I have been a fan since the first time I played the single player campaign.
What makes this special? Why should I buy this RTS? If you like RTS games, and enjoy a challenge this is the game for you.

This stands alone in the RTS world for many reasons. The 3D combat is truly 3D unlike other 3d perspective RTS games.  Persistence of units in the single player campaign is another major change to other RTS games that I have never seen. If you lose a unit in one mission it is gone forever. If you build a new ship of any kind it will follow you to the next mission as long as you can keep it alive. I have never seen this in any other RTS game like this. The economy side is a little simplistic but I personally don’t think it detracts from the game.  This is a 16 year old and 11 year old game, but it’s one of the best games I’ve ever played. Well worth the cost.

The atmosphere is second to none in the original. I enjoy the story in both, but the story is a little weak in the second game. The re-master is beautiful. I have not had anything bad to say so far.
I wish I could give it two thumbs up.

reviewText:
The Homeworld series is the prime example of a (space) RTS done right. Everything from level of detail on ships, to gameplay, to mod support, and optimization are excellent.

Now, I have a terrible gaming setup, a ATI Radeon 4350 graphics card with a AMD Phenom x4 910 processor. For those of you who don't speak computer hardware, this is a low end PC from back in like 2008. A piece of junk. Homeworld 2 ran great on it, and much to my surprise, so does the remastered edition. I have yet to see any serious frame issues despite playing it on a PC that is almost worth more as scrap metal than as a trade in. Granted, this is with most of the graphical settings turned low or off, but this just goes to show that you don't even need a decent computer to run the game.

But for those of you who haven't played Homeworld, here’s a little about the remastered edition of the game:

Its space RTS involving 4 races with up to 8 players. Each faction gets 4 different classes of units: Fighters, Corvettes, Frigates and Capital Ships with quite a few other utility class units. There are 2 Races from Homeworld 2, and 2 from the original Homeworld. There are significant differences between both generations, which is kind of interesting, especially when you consider the fact that both games are so fundamentally different, that they basically are incompatible with each other without serious modifications. Because of this, the devs, being so considerate of the loyal fan base, even decided to throw in the original untouched" versions of both Homeworld 1 AND Homeworld 2

reviewText: I never played Homeworld back when it came out, I was playing Starcraft and Warcraft.  Now I'm wishing I had. So long as Gearbox lives up to that, everyone should be happy.  Is it worth $35?  If you like space RTS games (of which there are pitiful few available) then yes.  If you liked Sins of a Solar Empire but wanted a campaign for it, then this is what you've always dreamed of.  Get it today.

reviewText: Homeworld Remastered Collection is a modern HD remake of two classic sci-fi real-time strategy games, Homeworld 1 and 2. Homeworld played like many other RTS games at the time: you'll command your star fleet, harvest resources, research technologies to build more ships, and attack other enemy fleets. However, in Homeworld, the game took place entirely in three-dimensional space, resulting in units not just moving horizontally, but also vertically, adding an extra tactical layer to the combat. Watching the combat between large groups of spaceships flying around each other was a sight to behold back then and now it looks even more amazing in the Remastered Collection. Gearbox has updated the visuals to modern standards and ships now have an incredible amount of detail. Even with the enhanced graphics, the game still manages to not be too demanding on hardware and it runs smoothly without any major stability issues. The user interface has also been updated for both games and it feels cleaner and more usable now. They even remastered the audio and the cutscenes with voice overs and music sounding much clearer and the animations looking more high-definition. The entire package isn't without its faults, however.\n\nThe remastered version of Homeworld 1 feels like it was ported over to the enhanced Homeworld 2 engine without properly adjusting and balancing the campaign for it. Ships won't stay in formation when attacking (might be just a bug for now), researching technologies costs resource units now, some prices for constructing ships have changed,  ship AI behavior seems to glitch out at times, and other minor differences. Worst of all, the remastered campaign seems to have borrowed the auto-balancing difficulty from the Homeworld 2 campaign. This might result in frustratingly difficult situations in some missions if you did too well in the last mission. Still, none of this is game-breaking and some might still enjoy the game and only have a few problems with it (especially those who have never played the game in the first place). All of this is sure to annoy veteran Homeworld players and hopefully Gearbox can fix some of it soon. At least the package inculdes the original Classic" version of Homeworld 1 which is still very playable and fun by today's standards

reviewText:
This deserves more than I'm going to write for now, so I'm going to add more later. But for now:

tl;dr: If you enjoy RTS games, games set in space, or amazing science fiction storylines (especially space operas), buy this. Buy it so hard. You will thank me.

Homeworld as a series has always been both thematically and mechanically beautiful-- I remember being in a trance watching the gameplay at a friend's house in 1999. From the agile and sleek scout ship to the mile-high Pride of Hiigara, no detail was spared. Combat was believably realistic and yet maintained a magical feeling of watching a high-tech waltz of destruction. Massive capital ships ran broadsides against each other while strike fighters battled in furballs. Flak exploded, plasma lanced, and ions beams sliced through space leaving a hot afterlight in your vision. It was everything I'd dreamed about for space battles, and Homeworld delivered above and beyond.

The story is nothing short of masterful. Narration both actively and passively help to build a universe where you truly feel for the people you are guiding. You feel their motivation, their need to complete their mission, and it is hard to pull yourself away from the game-- an active effort is required.

The Remastered collection is superb. Clearly, heart, soul, blood and tears went into the production, and it shows. You know how your mind's eye for the first games that you played always sharpened and enhanced as time went on? The story and graphics that you saw in your thoughts, instead of what was on screen? Remastered takes it from your head and puts it on screen. It looks, feels, and plays that well. This is what HD Remakes" should consider the master model

reviewText:
Before I start I just want to mention that I’m structuring this review for three key groups: people who are looking at Homeworld for the first time, the Homeworld 1 veterans, and the Homworld 2 veterans. Overall, this Remaster does get my thumbs up BUT in its current state there are still PLENTY of problems that need to be addressed (and therefore mentioned). I would also ask that you ignore my “play time” because sadly on my older laptop I have not been able to get Homeworld working properly, but my brother has (for the entire night in a span of about 10 hours) generously let me play on his account.

Now, let’s begin…

The Homeworld Experience for the new:

Homeworld is a 3D RTS type game that is done in real time and on xyz grids that allow full 3D gameplay (in comparison to 2D xy grid games such as Starcraft or Command and Conquer). If you are a fan of RTS games, be it the two games I have mentioned or Sins of a Solar Empire, you should definitely try this game. In this game, you start off with your “mother ship” and resource collectors, and your goal is to mine resources and research new ship types, and then build those ships to make fleets and then blow up your opponent. During this process, your enemy(s) will be doing the same thing, and there are even possible side objectives or challenges that can be undertaken to gain more resources to help further your cause. In the original games, there were already hundreds of different strategies utilized in multiplayer, but with these new side objectives and challenges it allows for even further diversity.

Factions are also extremely interesting to note: you have the factions from both original games, Homeworld 1 and 2, merged together in the same multiplayer experience. They are, to my surprise, actually quite balanced in gameplay. The game has really brought out the “rock paper scissors” aspect of what this game was originally about, but now with all 4 of the factions present there is a lot to take in and know what counters what, it can be a bit of a learning curve to memorize it all. This, in turn, adds to the diversity of strategy and player style you will see done by the AI and (especially) other human players.

And let’s not forget the campaigns. Two 16 mission journeys that put you through breath taking scenarios, all about a race of Humanoids that must make the journey back to their ancient home (Homeworld 1) and then defend it (Homeworld 2). Each campaign mission isn’t your standard “here you are, go blow up that person” and offer varieties of gameplay, such as in Homeworld 1 there is a mission where you can only use strike craft to complete your objective, or you have three minutes to destroy a massive ship that will ram right into your mothership if it is not taken out. Homeworld 2 offers the same mission diversity, and even gives you unique ships to fight and use throughout the campaign.  On top of that, the research method through both campaigns makes ships limited to specific types as you unlock more and more by progressing through the campaign, which allows players to get used to every single ship type and see their strengths and weaknesses, making the campaign not only fun and interesting, but all in all can be boiled down to a giant tutorial of how every single thing in Homeworld works.

On a final note, if you ever get bored with the remastered game, I highly recommend playing Homeworld 1 Classic, it features the original UI and game mechanics such as no unit cap in games that can be very fun to experiment with.

Seriously, if you Love RTS or space games and have not picked this title up yet, I seriously recommend you do so. It isn’t perfect, but I assure you that you are not only getting what your money ‘s worth but also are going to really enjoy it!

From the eyes of a Homeworld 1 Vet:

This section of the review focuses on the negative aspects and what has “survived” from the homeworld 1 game.

I think the biggest thing that irks me about the remastered Homeworld 1 is that they moved it to the Homeworld 2 user interface and model. In doing so they had to can a lot of Homeworld 1’s key features that made it stand out from its 2nd game, and now everyone I have talked to who preferred 1 over 2 has agreed with me that Homeworld 1 remastered just seems to be a decently gone mod for Homeworld 2.

The following is a list of features that are not in the remastered from Homeworld 1:

-Refueling: your strike craft can go anywhere infinitely without being tethered to anything, allowing them to operate in the game independently and much more of a threat to areas such as your resource operation.

-Harvesting:  in the first game, your harvesters flew around the asteroid and made them shrink as they collected resources (as well as dust clouds could be harvested). Here in remastered, they must dock with the asteroid to extract resources because of HW2’s

-Repair: ships have to dock with other ships to repair them. While this isn’t a change for strike craft, frigates, capital ships, and resource collectors could be repaired at a range in Homeworld 1

-The unit cap can’t be turned off in Multiplayer. This takes out a big chunk of what made some of the craziest HW battles that crazy (we’re talking hundreds of strike craft per person duking it out for superiority in a 6 person game)

Also, formations are a little annoying, and if you don’t believe me, I want you to go onto Homeworld 1 classic, build 9 ships, and put them into wall formation. You’ll get a nice 3x3 2d wall of the ships in a nice and orderly fashion. Do the same in HW1 remastered and you’ll get this weird cross thing with random gaps, and adding more ships to it just seems to make the cross bigger. Tactics are also screwed up with formations, and ships in specific tactics won’t always behave the same in formations the same ways that you might remember it from the Classic game. There is a new learning curve here (or bugs) that do need some attention whether you like it or not. Ships also have a tendency to partially break formation while moving (especially sphere), and on a small side note, sphere formationing ships and telling them to guard something won’t automatically make them form a sphere around the guarded ship. Again, this creates a small learning curve for the vets.

And we will complain about it, but it’s Homeworld, and we will still play it and eventually get used to it.


(more on the way)

reviewText:
If you have never played any of the other Home World games you are in for a treat, jaw dropping graphics, beautiful visuals, astonishing audio. If you have, leave your memories at the door, they will be shattered.

This is definitely not a remastered collection. This is little more than a re-imaging of HW2 with HW1 ships added in. If you have fond memories of the multiplayer lobby experience, don't come here expecting to make new ones, that key feature is totally absent and no plans are in the works currently to add one. This is definitely NOT a remastering of the originals.

If you can live with those differences more power to you, me, I give it the following scores:

Visuals: 5 out of 5
Audio: 4.5 out of 5
Controls: 2.5 out of 5
Game play Single play: 3.5 out of 5
Game play Multiplay: 2 out of 5*

*IMHO lack of a lobby seriously drops the score for multiplay, game play can be really fun, but no chance to talk with your team mates after a game or to discuss games in a lobby while waiting for games to start, really drops the longevity of the title.

reviewText:
Having finished the included HW1 campaign so far I feel I can put in a good review of this remaster effort.

First up getting it out of the way, we all know it but it must be said. The updated visuals are great! Not much more to be said there, the franchise has aged well visually, and now it looks even better.

Sound is good, though in some zoomed in situations it can get buggy. I suspect docked fighters may be emitting engine sounds currently, causing quite a racket. Other than that I don't recall any issues.

Gameplay is much improved with the HW2 style UI placed into the HW1 campaign. Sometimes the campaign difficulty can be brutal, but at least you won’t find yourself needlessly losing so many ships due to fighting against the interface and AI behavior.
The addition of HW2 style end mission resource collection is also going to save you hours of work and fill your pockets between missions. Rather than having to seek out every pocket of resources on a map manually long after your objectives are complete, you can now simply hyperspace jump out and watch all remaining resources auto-deposit into your stores. This combined with smart battle management means you won’t be so dangerously broke all the time.

Bugs I've observed in a 9 hour playthrough of the remastered HW1 campaign:
-At least 3 times a keypress ('esc' did it one time) has caused my game space to go black. Fixed by saving, then re-loading that save.
-Occasionally small objects will confuse AI navigation, either bumping into them, or treating them as large invisible walls. On the last level I had to fly high over a sparse asteroid belt that I don't recall being an obstacle in the original.
- I had ONE full game crash that happened at random. not too bad for 9 hours of play on day one.

I highly recommend this game to those looking to replay a classic, and those trying it for the first time. The campaigns will throw a lot of curve balls at you, and having to restart a mission, or even loading up from an earlier mission will be necessary at times, but at the core level I think this is an easy RTS to pick up, not to mention the great story.

reviewText:
This game is amazing, but the MP is in beta so there are bugs for some.  They ported the HW2 engine onto the HW1 which seems to have messed with certain HW1 game mechanics.  However, Gearbox is addressing these issues.

I have had a lot of fun playing the multiplayer.  It pits the HW1 races against the HW2 races, but because of the engine porting, there are definite balance issues if you play as a HW1 race.  To avoid this, I just play as HW2 for now, which as a die-hard HW fan, is still pretty amazing.

Gearbox is invested in this series, so we should expect continued support and updates from them. They released a critical fix update just a week after release.  There are definite improvements that need to be made and since the development team is looking at this series with such dedication and love, I can only see good things coming.

Another bright spot, lots and lots of mod support.  This is where the series will also shine.  Considering there was very little mod support for the originals and such great mods were released anyway, one can only imagine the amazing work the modding community will put out.

It's a niche game still and not many will like the RTS style, but I like that about it. In my option, it attracts a certain higher caliber of gamer.

reviewText:
Overall this remaster is great and definitely worth buying if you like RTS games.  I rank it my 2nd favorite RTS of all time behind the original Starcraft and its expansion.  Heres my review of it:

The good:
The art is amazing.  The remastered textures, sounds, music, and models are all more than I had hoped for.  The new visual effects make the game as impressive today as it was when it was first released (the HW1 graphics were amazing for when it came out in 99).  Playing through the story is as fun and enjoyable as I remember it being.  I'll be spending a lot more time playing this for the next few weeks.  I like how my capital ships stay grouped up and in formation after hyperspacing from one mission to the next, that saves a lot of time setting them up.

I haven't gotten around to Homeworld 2's campaign yet, but I doubt I'll be disappointed there.  That game is still easy to pick up and play today as it was 10 years ago.  So the graphical update to it will do little but make everything better.

The Bad:
While the remaster is great there are many changes from HW1->HWRM.  There are a lot of core changes to gameplay when the game was translated over to the new engine, many of which affected the strength of support craft, fighters, and corvettes in negative ways.  Such as:
* Fighter/corvette formations having no effect on their behavior in a fight.  Corvettes don't face their targets when circling, meaning certain types of corvettes only use half of their guns in a fight.  This hurts Kushan the most because of the way their guns are laid out.
* Guard works completely differently making it impossible to form defensive corvette walls and fighter balls.
* Support craft healing abilities require them to be right next to the craft they are healing, as opposed to a comfortable distance away.  Making them both slower to heal because they have to maneuver into position and less effective because they cannot respond as quickly.  It also means two support frigates cannot heal each other.  They just circle around each other trying to sniff each others butts, like a pair of dogs.
* Ships have wierd accuracy issues.  Many times their shots are no where near their targets, even when their target is stationary.
* You can only build 2 units at a time.  In the original you could build 2-3 of each unit type simultaneously for a total 10+ units being built at one time (3 fighters, and 2 of each of the other types).  And that isn't even counting a carrier.
* Research now costs RU and having multiple research vessels does not let you research multiple technologies at once.  Previously research was free and you could designate either a single or multiple research vessels to either research multiple things at once or one or two things very quickly.
* Resource collectors will sometimes completely ignore patches of resources and claim that the map is dry.
* Everything is less reponsive.  I think this is due to the engine, but I every click and command was crisp and responsive from the original.  In the new engine everything just feels more floaty.  Kinda like Starcraft 1 -> Starcraft 2 responsiveness.  I don't know why this is so hard to achieve in newer games but its something I've noticed.

Because of that, the game plays about 60-70% accurate to the original.

The Ugly:
Of the new remastered graphics I'm very impressed with the missile effects ... when zoomed in.  When zoomed out they aren't there, and you can barely tell where the missiles are by the small missile pods.  In the original you could clearly see missile trails even when fully zoomed out.  And the ending credits are missing the music from Yes, but I heard that was due to a licensing issue.  If you want to see the original credits in their glory just visit youtube.  I have crashed once, and when getting back in game it completely screwed up my hotkeys in a mission where I really needed them to work from the start.  And finally, you need a Shift" account to play multiplayer.  Its completely pointless to make one because they then force you to link it to your steam account before you can play.  Why couldn't you just use my steam account to begin with?

I definitely recommend this game
date: but if you don't mind old graphics for HW1 you will find the original actually plays much better than the remaster.  As for HW2 its probably a direct upgrade
recommended: since this is just a modified HW2 engine the game is running on."

reviewText:
Homeworld is a great game, a great franchise that deserved this great remaster.

That being said, you must note that HW1 was basically ported to HW2, so if you are a HW veteran that absolutely despised the HW2 gameplay mechanics, you might find yourself disappointed.

For everyone else, including those who never played any Homeworld game, this will be no problem at all - it's mostly a matter of personal taste.

Only real downside to the game at this point: The balance.
I have played through the HW1 SP campaign so far and I must say that after you get the strongest type of warship available, the game does get too easy.
But Gearbox has assured us that balance (esp. in Multiplayer) is not final and will be worked on. (Thus Multiplayer BETA)
And if all else fails, there will certainly be mods. HW2 has a very active and ingenious modding community and the remaster has been tendered to offer good mod support.

So please don't take this warning as a turnoff, because otherwise, you would be missing out on a great RTS game like no other. Definitive recommendation from me.

reviewText:
Note - This review is ONLY for Homeworld 1 Remastered, I haven't started playing HW2 yet.

'Breathtaking'  is a word I wouldn't normally apply to an RTS, but I think it genuinely fits here.  The audiovisual presentation of Homeworld : Remastered immerses you in the vastness of space, and manages to make each stage in the empty void feel varied and colorful.

Gameplay wise, you've got a fairly difficult single player campaign that forces you to learn the ins and outs of the various spaceships so you can counter your enemies in a rock paper scissors like fashion.  It's nothing groundbreaking, but it is balanced quite well, and generally feels logical and fair.

The story this game tells is also genuinely interesting, and unique.  I have yet to finish the single player campaign but I am already curious to see where things are going and what the truth is about the various factions I have encountered thus far.

So .. yeah.  I recommend this game to anyone who likes playing beautiful looking RTS,  and likes a good story.   I'm not going to compare it to the original homeworld because I never actually played HW1 ( only HW2 ).   Compared to the original HW2, the remaster of HW1 feels similar, but it's been like 10 years since I played it, so take that with a grain of salt :)

Well done Gearbox!

reviewText:
If you had a tear blinking in your eye when you heard the theme music after 16 years, welcome friend, this remaster will give everything you need to bring back old memories, in HD!

Homeworld had redefined the RTS games 16 years ago with its unique 3D space view where you could command your fleet not only horizontally but vertically. Since there is no terrain here, strategies are diverse, entrapping the enemy fleet in a crescent shaped formation was never more satisfactory.

Combining the original beautiful story with immense graphics after 16 years, Homeworld Remastered Collection is definitely a must buy for both the old gamers who will re-enjoy everyhing in a more eye-appeasing manner but also for the people who have never heard of it, for this is the game coming from the best times of PC strategy gaming, where story and gameplay elements were put forward than hollow graphics. Good point is, now you can have both!

Only downside of this collection is that it does not contain another classic; Homeworld Cataclysm. I would really like to go through the story of mere miners of Kuun-Lan against the vile Beast, but seems like the source code of the game was lost when Barking Dog Studios hit the dust.

Overall, this collection is a must buy for all RTS lovers and dinosaur" players who have lived to see when this game rose for the first time.

"The Mothership standing by""

reviewText:
Is it a cash grab? Most remasters, absolutely. This remaster, however, shows an incredible amount of care given to the resurrection of a timeless classic, an IP that still has a great deal of potential.

In order to make such an incredibly faithful remastering, key artists from the original art team were hired to breath new life into the graphics and the original composer was brought in to touch up the soundtrack. As such, everything has been retouched with an incredible amount of care and respect.

True, some mechanics have been changed across both games (the first one most of all). Purists will be disappointed to be missing out on some mechanics, such as strikecreaft fuel, and some missions will be changed somewhat as a result. However, I believe that those omissions that were made in the remastered editions were for the better, in order to create more consistent games over all. I haven't tried them yet, but if you really want the original experience all over again, the Classic versions are bundled along with the rest.

Considering all of these things in addition to subtle improvements to the HUD in both games, full modding support, the addition of a steam-supported multiplayer, and even fleshed out options menus, I can say that Homeworld has been reborn and that it can very easily compete with many modern RTS games in terms of immersion, challenge, and depth. With any luck, this will be the jump start that the IP needs as a whole.

... and now back to my fleet of salvage ships!

reviewText:
Homeworld 2 absorbed my time for quite a while, and I regretted not having beat Homeworld 1, but the game was just too old and felt too clunky to hold my interest.

So I bought this. Honestly this is hands down the best 'remaster' of any game I've ever played. It feels like it was developed this year, the visuals are crispy, the controls are improved as well as the interface.

And this game has not changed. The story is still amazing. The music is still haunting. It will still kick your butt. This isn't your classic 'turtle and hoard' RTS. You're going to lose a few missions. You're going to have to adapt your strategies. In other words, its Real Time, clench your cheeks and make with the Strategy.

I would recommend this to anyone who likes the genre, and to anyone looking to try the genre.

reviewText:
Since the vast majority of negative reviews here are misleading and either nitpick or make vague and uninformative complaints about failed launches, I figured I would give you guys a more comprehensive first impression of Homeworld Remastered. Before I start though, know that I haven't played the original Homeworlds and am new to the series. Also, the in-depth review will come a bit later, given that I've only played for a couple of hours.

Here's a quick summary of the game's pro's and con's.

Pros:
+ Satisfyingly simple yet beautiful visuals

+ Ease of use [I was reticent about how easy it would be to control fleets given the scope of the game and my inability to micro efficiently but the controls are spot on].

+ Audio---I can't stress this enough. Gearbox got the original developpers to contribute their original audio files—UNCOMPRESSED—for the remastered game. If you have headphones that are half decent or, ideally, have dolby 7.1, you're in for a treat. Also, the zoom level will give you access to different levels of audio. Zoomed out? You have the audio of high ranked officers and frigates. Zoomed in? You hear the dogfighting grunt screaming for his life as he's blown up.

+ Story: The narrative does a good job at not holding your hand too much. It drew me right in during the first few missions, and combined with the audio and headache free controls, nothing is really in the way of you experiencing the story without any hassles.

+Depth. Again, I can't stress this enough. Try to imagine a complicated hierarchy of ships and tiers, combine that with coordinated strikeforces which utilize altitude and formations, combined with a great two tier command system of macro and micro commands, and you get a fantastically intricate rts which flirts with becoming overwhelming but never quite gets there.

Cons:
- While the graphics are satisfying, there are certain elements that seem a little oldschool. While I know this was done to maintain the nostalgiac visuals of the original, you get some weird combination of amazing textures on the mothership with odd and clunky parts.

- The learning curve. If you're not into strategy games or are looking for something to easily jump into, this might not be the game for you. It's not a simple point and click. Like I mentioned, you have a 3d plane of combat, so you have to worry about attacks from above and below, as well as front, back and side. Also, if you weren't really into space themed games, distinguishing a corvette from a frigate from a carrier will take some memorization.


Honestly, forget these chumps who are using steam reviews as a support or troubleshooting forum. They don't post specs, probally haven't even attempted to take the most basic steps in fixing these problems, and are just firing off Not Recommended" left and right. While I acknowledge that my experience
recommended: won't be the same for others
hoursPlayed: I think that a certain level of patience is in order given that it's launch day. I've seen AAA titles have much more horrific launches than this gem of a game.\n\nA B-List gamers review. Check us out on the Curators page for similar reviews."

reviewText:
If you had a tear blinking in your eye when you heard the theme music after 16 years, welcome friend, this remaster will give everything you need to bring back old memories, in HD!

Homeworld had redefined the RTS games 16 years ago with its unique 3D space view where you could command your fleet not only horizontally but vertically. Since there is no terrain here, strategies are diverse, entrapping the enemy fleet in a crescent shaped formation was never more satisfactory.

Combining the original beautiful story with immense graphics after 16 years, Homeworld Remastered Collection is definitely a must buy for both the old gamers who will re-enjoy everyhing in a more eye-appeasing manner but also for the people who have never heard of it, for this is the game coming from the best times of PC strategy gaming, where story and gameplay elements were put forward than hollow graphics. Good point is, now you can have both!

Only downside of this collection is that it does not contain another classic; Homeworld Cataclysm. I would really like to go through the story of mere miners of Kuun-Lan against the vile Beast, but seems like the source code of the game was lost when Barking Dog Studios hit the dust.

Overall, this collection is a must buy for all RTS lovers and dinosaur" players who have lived to see when this game rose for the first time.

"The Mothership standing by""

reviewText:
One of the best remaster's Gearbox has made. It's beatiful graphics are breathless especially coming from a 15 year old game which back then had 16-Bit pologon graphics form to make 3D models. It's audio remade into something that you would hear nowadays on most AAA games. The soundtrack is well remade and nostalgic for veterans like me and most of the other dedicated fans and players of this franchise. The story is well told and it's lore interesting and it's antagonists really likable to go up against.
There are bugs like any other game and some odd design choices which can put off some gamers. It's diffiult to control at first but you'll get the hang of it after a few plays. The A.I. is pretty smart and clever and will be a challenge for players especially in campaign. The strategies and tips used from the classics unfortunatle are obsolete in the remastered so the missions are to be unexpected as we still don't understand how the game can be played in the players favor: where in the classics there was an exploit which used right would give the player great advantage over the A.I. in the campaign. A lot of the veterans complain saying its rather dissappointing and buggy and not worked out. I beg to differ. It's a really good rts game even if its buggy at it's release and realistically speaking almost every game thats released has bugs and complications upon release but it's not so bad as other games released recently by big name companies. In due time hoipefully things will get patched up and mods worked on and created to where this game is even MORE enjoyable.

Pros
-Amazing graphics
-Great audio remake
-Aamazing OST
-Story
-A.I.
-Interesting factions to play
-Mods
-Community

Cons-
-Formations broken
-Damges done to certain crafts especially frigates bug out and become shooting dummies
-Tactics broken
-Some minor visual glitches here and there from time to time
-Crashes after hours of continous gameplay
-Pop cap(Is that really necessary to have especially since modern machines are powerful enough to hold massive fleets.)
-Multiplayer in Beta

Overall this is a wonderful masterpiece from an underrated game. Highly recommend this to anyone interested in space battles,rts's,tactics etc. or anyone starting out with rts games. For those new to the franchise or never heard of it. They also included the classic first to games to play on as well to compare and try out as well and it's also for the veterans who lost their copy(like me :( ) as getting ahold of a physical copy of this game is like a needle in a haystack nowadays so why hassle your time in finding a physical copy of the older two games when it's included in this digital bundle.

9/10

P.S.-It's a shame that Cataclysm can't be remastered(source code is missing and is unable to be found) as that was a good game as well that was part of the Homeworld franchise and that too is difficult to get ahold of a physical copy.

reviewText:
Homeworld. It used to be considered one of best RTS's ever made set in space combat. After it was remastered it still is one of best RTS's ever created. I have never played original games, bought the game during recent steam sale. Money well spent. The game is just amazing. Homeworld 1 Remastered feels like one is playing Battlestar Galactica (2003-2009). On the other hand Homeworld 2 Remastered is more of war story while keeping up mysticism of 1st game.
First thing I can tell you now the game is not easy, You need to learn its controls and how it works otherwise you will keep loosing. When you learn ropes of the game its extremely pleasant to play and most importantly enemy will still outnumber you, i.e. in 2nd game the enemy will have 10 battlecruisers while you have a cap allowing you to build 2 bc's. Quite unfair considering their firepower but frigates are perfect cannon fodder for that :P

Story of two games is just amazing, both cause you feel rush and despair. Graphics in comparison to original game imporved really well fitting modern standards (including 4k if u can handle it). The soundtrack is purely amazing and is used in appropriate moments to affect us as players when necessary. Adagio for Strings choral by Samuel Barber is actually one of most beautiful songs ever created in our history. Yes, its used in best moments in the Homeworld 1 Remastered! Other soundtrack is also amazing but this very specific song is purest masterpiece of all,

Gameplay. It's great. Cant say anything more. Combat is balanced, fights are challanging and its easy to loose if you're not using the thing in ur head at all. This is defiently not casual game where you hop in and immediately become a god in it (like designers of modern games do nowadays with games is just wrong!) Nothing beats sight of full scale fleet vs fleet combat. Bloody yet stunning.

Homeworld Remastered Collection is great offer. You get 4 games (2 original + 2 remastered games) and if you are considering to buy it, do not hesitate. You will not regret spending your money on the game (sale or normally). Right now I feel like a thief for buying on summer sale. This game is worth way more than I've paid for it.
I feel like I want to keep returning to the game to play it over and over. It is that good, great replayability value and satisfaction from it.

To sum things up:

+ Nicely improved graphics that fits modern standards
+ Masterpiece soundtrack (and im quite hard to impress with music)
+ Great Gameplay and replayability value
+ Great story that actually makes you feel desperate, in rush
+ Want more!
+ Not casual...

- ... which for some console peasants will be a bad thing.
- some bugs
- not well explained graphic settings in the video settings

reviewText:
(As of this writing I have only played Homeworld Remastered, not 2)
I was a bit hesitant to purchase this due to the fear that these games weren't as great as I had remembered. I was relieved to find out that Homeworld holds up to the test of time and in this remastered version it looks better than ever.

The one thing I remembered about Homeworld was the atmosphere which is enhanced ten fold thanks to the remastering. Nothing compares to sending in a large armada full of fighters, corvettes, ion frigates and destroyers against another force of equal measure and watching the battle play out. Fighters whip around in the void dodging fire and letting loose upon the opposition. Destroyers fire heavy volleys of missles and projectiles which crash into the enemy's ranks. Ships flame out and tumble into an explosion when destroyed or in the case of capital ships they spin around and emit a huge fireball complete with debris. When the battle seems lost you can order your remaining fighters to kamikaze in a last ditch attempt to save the mothership. The backdrops are incredibly beautiful and stunning to look at. This remastered edition makes the game look like I remember it looking.

Now with all that being said there is a bit of jank. Scripting has a tendancy to break. Movement commands get a little fuddled sometimes. I have had a handful of weird audio bugs as well. The zooming in and out via the mousewheel is a bit weird considering the setting being in 3d space you would think you could just keep zooming out to move the field of view up but you can't. A small amount of other issues have me scratching my head sometimes.

Taking all that into consideration Homeworld has always had a special place in my heart. This remastered edition has me skipping and jumping for joy down memory lane as I relive all those massive space battles I remembered having. If you have any reverance for these games buy this edition right now. If this is new to you I encourage giving it a shot. If you aren't hooked before the first two hours of play you can always get a refund through Steam but I am pretty confident if you like space, explosions and strategy you will find a place in your heart for Homeworld as well.

reviewText:
Homeworld is a space RTS game released in 1999, it gained popularity by not only creating the single most intuitive space strategy mechanic to date, but also had an amazing story line and one of the most beautiful music scores ever. In Homeworld and Homeworld 2, resource management is key, every resource you collect on one mission gets transferred to your next, so it is a good idea to use it wisely, often relying on salvage ships to steal enemy ships over building your own. Space combat is done on a fully 3D plane, where ships can easily move in all 3 axis, which at the time was revolutionary.

Gearbox did an amazing job in remastering this great gem, the graphics is amazing, while keeping the story and the music intact the game is truly perfect now. They made some UI and control changes but in the end it results in a smoother gameplay.

There are a few minor bugs such as a sound issue with ship engines when too many of them are moving at once, and the tutorial being slightly broken (you get asked to press okay to continue to the next segment but the tutorial continues on as if you already pressed it), however these are minor gripes and does nothing to ruin this wonderful title.

My ratings are as follows:
Graphics 8
Music 10
Story 10
Gameplay 9

reviewText:
Firstly as a big fan of the original homeworld games, I admit I had high hopes for this 'remaster', it was sold on the premise that we'd be getting the original games brought up to date. Which is only half true.

In the case of HW2 they delivered, the game plays just like the original, and looks amazing. The game is exactly as expected, so I have no complaints there at all.

So in conclusion, I am going to recommend this game on the merits of the HW2 remaster, but stress that if HW1 was your favourite of the two then you are going to be sorely disappointed.

reviewText:
I have played the original Homeworld & Homeworld 2 since years back and I am really happy that they made a remaster of both of the games. I recently finished the Homeworld & Homeworld 2 remastered campaign and it was absolutely brilliant. Imagine your greatest gaming moments returned to life with better graphics and smoother gameplay.

The nostalgia may play a big part in why I like this game, but I'll try my best to tell you the about the remastered version and the differences between the remastered versions and classic versions.



+ The three dimensional movement & combat is astonishing to look at and easy to control.
+ The story is great and really gives the game an amazing atmosphere around it while you play it.
+ The updated Homeworld 2 UI (which is used in both remastered version of the game) is easy to understand and use.
+ They captured the emptiness of space perfectly and it really sets the mood while you are playing the game.
+ The multiplayer has also been updated. You are able to play as Taiidan, Vaygr, Kushan and Hiigaran on restored maps with new bonuses and game modes that I've had loads of fun with after the campaign.
+ The game is slower paced than games like Starcraft, which means, you don't have to have super fast micro managing skills to be able to play well).
+ The game is easy to mod and uses steam workshop.

-+ The fuel system has been removed from the remastered versions (This was a system that could be seen as annoying or just another gameplay element depending on what the player thinks. The reason that the gameplay element was removed was probably because of the annoyance of having your ships becoming completely static in the middle of combat.)

- The Homeworld & Homeworld 2 races are a bit unbalanced against eachother in multiplayer (Keep in mind that the multiplayer is still development).
- The Resource collecting can be a bit buggy sometimes. For example: when recource collecters want to collect debris from shipwrecks.
- Some cool and useful attack patterns and strategies have been changed since the both remastered versions are runing on an updated Homeworld 2 engine.


Overall, this game is truly a RTS masterpiece and is, AT LEAST, a must try for those who enjoy RTS.

reviewText:
I was a big fan of Homeworld back in the day, so couldn't wait to play the Remastered version.

It's still a good game, and looks fantastic, but compared to Sins of a Solar Empire (the other great space RTS), Homeworld Remastered seems extremely dated.

I'm very surprised at how boring I find the gameplay, and how unexciting the battles are too, despite the glorious effects and ship models. Sins allows for huge RTS space battles too, but they are really thrilling, and because you can name you ships, and because they can gain expereince, there's a great connection between you and individual ships.

I'm really looking forward to where the Homeworld franchise goes however, as it obviously has a huge amount of potential.

If you've never played the original Homeworld game, you'll probably still love this game. However, this game deviates from the original game's style and gameplay mechanics for me to recommend it to a fan.

reviewText:
I played through Homeworld twice in my youth and fondly revisited it every few years thereafter. But this remaster doesn't do it justice. Not only is it buggier than a Stalker launch, but it has gone unfixed for months. As you know from other critical analysis videos, HWR lacks proper squad and tactics mechanics, resulting in poorly balanced ships, frustrating RNG mechanics, and fewer strategic options. What I wasn't aware of are the following:

Mission scripts break every other mission. Unwinnable states, no completion trigger, in game cutscenes perform oddly when queued waypoints or battles are occuring in the background. AI isn't allowed to hyperspace in while a cutscene plays, so you can complete objectives before they ever finish.

Fleet difficulty scaling results in rather comical scenarios. At the Ghost Ship, there was a massive cluster of 30  assault frigates already, simply because my fleet size was out of control. With some baiting, I easily added those to my collection too... and the snowball effect is starting to lag my later missions, especially movement lines are rendered and overlaid. Every time the mission begins, your ships are lined up to the left of your mothership. Now my ships are so numerous they span twice the map's distance... beginning from the edge of the map! You begin the later missions under immediate attack by 100+ ships, while 80% of your own fleet spawns so far away, it would take 10 minutes for them to reach your mothership, making these missions unwinnable unless I reloaded a previous mission and retired the majority of my fleet.

Multi-target (boxed) salvage and repair commands are not working. There is a salvage hotkey which actually does nothing in HWR, and repair results in the repair ship flipping between targets until it succumbs to paralysis. HW was great because it emphasized that you were akin to Karan Sjet. You had control over a massive number of units without the logistical nightmare, and micro was not necessary, as units would automatically target units they were best at, and sort out who they'd repair first and manage themselves at best efficiency. I have never given as many single target orders in all my HW playthroughs as I have in half a HWR campaign. It's tedious, and I certainly don't feel like I have a neural connection to my fleet.

There is a new mission timer that shows how long you've spent on a mission. Except it resets to 0 every time you load a save. This is immediately noticable... Did Gearbox even test their new features?

Antialiasing impedes certain map elements (dust veins) from rendering visibly, critical to a certain mission.

Autosaves actually occur a minute after the start of a mission, which means if the mission/trigger states are broken, they stay broken in the autosave. Use mission restart, NOT the autosave.

It's been months. Where are the patches?

reviewText:
Impressively broken.

Resource collectors get stuck in thin air doing nothing while there are resources on the map. In the original I never had to worry about them, they would mine out the map. Here I have to babysit them constantly and spam the Harvest command every 2 minutes or they will get stuck. Also if you blow up an enemy capital ship they leave behind debris that can be collected, and that routine is COMPLETELY broken, all collectors will queue up to pick up the same chuck of metal and then they will do nothing even if you use the Harvest command. You also can't return those to a resource controller, you have to take them back to the mothership which may be 5 minutes away, during which time you are basically not mining anything because all collectors are stuck. Wow.

Formations do nothing, they only work out of combat. When you are fighting, ships just break formation and go all over the place, so you can't micromanage or focus fire anything, you just CTRL-click and pray.

The AI is broken. When you are under attack by a fleet, every enemy ship is prioritizing your salvage corvettes. If you dock them, they just kind of don't know what to do anymore, they just fly around taking occasional pot shots at your fighters until they get blown up. Your resource collectors never get harassed, I had them mining right next to an enemy fleet and nobody bothered them, instead they went for my salvage corvettes who were 20 km away.

Audio is messed up, engine sounds will occasionally stop working or burst into static and kill your ears.

Adaptive difficulty is a mess and very easy to abuse. If you leave the Kadesh missions with 25k RU's hoarded up and only build what you need when you need it, the campaign is a faceroll from that point on. You don't even need to capture anything ever, in fact it would be best to retire your salvage corvettes, thus breaking the enemy AI and having them fly around like headless chickens.

Multiplayer is unstable and in beta.

Just....ugh. The game needs like a year of patching, I'm not even sure if it's fixable at this point. Or if they will bother. DON'T buy this yet. Wait to see what they patch and wait for a sale.

reviewText:
When I was around 14 or so, I remember heading to a friend's house where he and his brothers had a number of gaming PCs set up, all networked in and online. We would play Everquest, Counterstrike, and a number of other games into the wee hours of the morning. There was one game there that stood out to me; that game was Homeworld.

Homeworld is an amazing game. A journey through both an amazing, emotional story and wonderful gameplay. The score is driving, the visuals are breathtaking, and the whole experience is awesome.

If you played this game at original release, then I'm sure you remember the first time loading it up, hearing Samuel Barber's Angus Dei and seeing the Mothership. I know you can recall the emotion felt when the fleet returns to Kharak only to find it burning under an enemy assault. Countless memories flood forth from the mere mention of this cult jewel. Why it wasn't more popular at the time, I will never know.

A friend and I would play this title over Gameranger. We did for a good many years, actually. We would always joke about them doing an updated version of the game (if not a HW 3)...well, those jokes have become a reality. An awesome reality.

If you're a fan of the original, or curious about this game...I say go for it. It is worth every penny.

If you are new to the game, I envy you....you're about to take an amazing journey on your way home.

alright, before I begin I want to point out that I played the originals a long time ago. So when This came out, I went on a nostalgia trip. But, I will try my best to be fair in this.

reviewText: I would like to recommend this game, but I currently can't. The classic games are missing LAN support and high resolution support/widescreen support wasn't added. I only played for around about an hour and finished the first two missions.  That was about all I could take.

I loved Homeworld, Cataclysm and Homeworld 2. I own them all so I thought getting the remaster would be a nice idea...especially with the summer sale and the contents of my Steam Wallet making it cost me less than a tenner.

So I built up my Corvettes and attempted to put them in a wall formation, they went into a Diamond formation no matter what number of them I used. They would then attempt to chase said fighters even though they are slower.

I swear I had 12 Heavy Corvettes defending the Salvage Corvette in the second mission and it almost died to a small squad of Turanic fighters that the AI in my Corvettes refused to kill.

I think it's a given that I'm going to refund this utter turd. Feel so let down!

If you like Homeworld, DO NOT BUY THIS GAME!
