reviewText:
I played through Homeworld twice in my youth and fondly revisited it every few years thereafter. But this remaster doesn't do it justice. Not only is it buggier than a Stalker launch, but it has gone unfixed for months. As you know from other critical analysis videos, HWR lacks proper squad and tactics mechanics, resulting in poorly balanced ships, frustrating RNG mechanics, and fewer strategic options. What I wasn't aware of are the following:

Mission scripts break every other mission. Unwinnable states, no completion trigger, in game cutscenes perform oddly when queued waypoints or battles are occuring in the background. AI isn't allowed to hyperspace in while a cutscene plays, so you can complete objectives before they ever finish.

Fleet difficulty scaling results in rather comical scenarios. At the Ghost Ship, there was a massive cluster of 30  assault frigates already, simply because my fleet size was out of control. With some baiting, I easily added those to my collection too... and the snowball effect is starting to lag my later missions, especially movement lines are rendered and overlaid. Every time the mission begins, your ships are lined up to the left of your mothership. Now my ships are so numerous they span twice the map's distance... beginning from the edge of the map! You begin the later missions under immediate attack by 100+ ships, while 80% of your own fleet spawns so far away, it would take 10 minutes for them to reach your mothership, making these missions unwinnable unless I reloaded a previous mission and retired the majority of my fleet.

Multi-target (boxed) salvage and repair commands are not working. There is a salvage hotkey which actually does nothing in HWR, and repair results in the repair ship flipping between targets until it succumbs to paralysis. HW was great because it emphasized that you were akin to Karan Sjet. You had control over a massive number of units without the logistical nightmare, and micro was not necessary, as units would automatically target units they were best at, and sort out who they'd repair first and manage themselves at best efficiency. I have never given as many single target orders in all my HW playthroughs as I have in half a HWR campaign. It's tedious, and I certainly don't feel like I have a neural connection to my fleet.

There is a new mission timer that shows how long you've spent on a mission. Except it resets to 0 every time you load a save. This is immediately noticable... Did Gearbox even test their new features?

Antialiasing impedes certain map elements (dust veins) from rendering visibly, critical to a certain mission.

Autosaves actually occur a minute after the start of a mission, which means if the mission/trigger states are broken, they stay broken in the autosave. Use mission restart, NOT the autosave.

It's been months. Where are the patches?

reviewText:
Impressively broken.

Resource collectors get stuck in thin air doing nothing while there are resources on the map. In the original I never had to worry about them, they would mine out the map. Here I have to babysit them constantly and spam the Harvest command every 2 minutes or they will get stuck. Also if you blow up an enemy capital ship they leave behind debris that can be collected, and that routine is COMPLETELY broken, all collectors will queue up to pick up the same chuck of metal and then they will do nothing even if you use the Harvest command. You also can't return those to a resource controller, you have to take them back to the mothership which may be 5 minutes away, during which time you are basically not mining anything because all collectors are stuck. Wow.

Formations do nothing, they only work out of combat. When you are fighting, ships just break formation and go all over the place, so you can't micromanage or focus fire anything, you just CTRL-click and pray.

The AI is broken. When you are under attack by a fleet, every enemy ship is prioritizing your salvage corvettes. If you dock them, they just kind of don't know what to do anymore, they just fly around taking occasional pot shots at your fighters until they get blown up. Your resource collectors never get harassed, I had them mining right next to an enemy fleet and nobody bothered them, instead they went for my salvage corvettes who were 20 km away.

Audio is messed up, engine sounds will occasionally stop working or burst into static and kill your ears.

Adaptive difficulty is a mess and very easy to abuse. If you leave the Kadesh missions with 25k RU's hoarded up and only build what you need when you need it, the campaign is a faceroll from that point on. You don't even need to capture anything ever, in fact it would be best to retire your salvage corvettes, thus breaking the enemy AI and having them fly around like headless chickens.

Multiplayer is unstable and in beta.

Just....ugh. The game needs like a year of patching, I'm not even sure if it's fixable at this point. Or if they will bother. DON'T buy this yet. Wait to see what they patch and wait for a sale.

reviewText: In it's current state, Homeworld Remastered is a fundamentally broken game. The philosophy of rebuilding the Homeworld 1 campaign in the Homeworld 2 Engine sounds good on paper, but in practice it leads to the butchering of all the mechanics that made Homeworld 1 great. Formations are now broken and cannot be used as they were in Homeworld classic. This leads to drawn out battles that would have been decisive in the classic version. If you can go beyond the fresh coat of paint the game has been given and look under the hood you will see that the core mechanics just are not there anymore. People who are praising this as a great re-master are only looking at the surface and have probably never actually played the original. This is not Homeworld 1 anymore, it is only Homeworld 2 with Homeworld 1 sloppily attached.\n\nIf you only are interested in Homeworld 2 (which you really should not be) then you will not find any complaints. But if you want Homeworld 1, you are better off sticking to the classic.

(Disclaimer: This is for those who played and loved the very first Homeworld)

I love the Homeworld series. It is beautiful in story and visuals, and fantastic gameplay and mechanics in the classics.

(Homeworld 1 RM review)

Unit A.I. isn't all that good (I.E. strike craft tend to crash into asteroids and other objects in some missions)

reviewText:
(As of this writing I have only played Homeworld Remastered, not 2)
I was a bit hesitant to purchase this due to the fear that these games weren't as great as I had remembered. I was relieved to find out that Homeworld holds up to the test of time and in this remastered version it looks better than ever.

The one thing I remembered about Homeworld was the atmosphere which is enhanced ten fold thanks to the remastering. Nothing compares to sending in a large armada full of fighters, corvettes, ion frigates and destroyers against another force of equal measure and watching the battle play out. Fighters whip around in the void dodging fire and letting loose upon the opposition. Destroyers fire heavy volleys of missles and projectiles which crash into the enemy's ranks. Ships flame out and tumble into an explosion when destroyed or in the case of capital ships they spin around and emit a huge fireball complete with debris. When the battle seems lost you can order your remaining fighters to kamikaze in a last ditch attempt to save the mothership. The backdrops are incredibly beautiful and stunning to look at. This remastered edition makes the game look like I remember it looking.

Now with all that being said there is a bit of jank. Scripting has a tendancy to break. Movement commands get a little fuddled sometimes. I have had a handful of weird audio bugs as well. The zooming in and out via the mousewheel is a bit weird considering the setting being in 3d space you would think you could just keep zooming out to move the field of view up but you can't. A small amount of other issues have me scratching my head sometimes.

Taking all that into consideration Homeworld has always had a special place in my heart. This remastered edition has me skipping and jumping for joy down memory lane as I relive all those massive space battles I remembered having. If you have any reverance for these games buy this edition right now. If this is new to you I encourage giving it a shot. If you aren't hooked before the first two hours of play you can always get a refund through Steam but I am pretty confident if you like space, explosions and strategy you will find a place in your heart for Homeworld as well.

reviewText:
Homeworld is a space RTS game released in 1999, it gained popularity by not only creating the single most intuitive space strategy mechanic to date, but also had an amazing story line and one of the most beautiful music scores ever. In Homeworld and Homeworld 2, resource management is key, every resource you collect on one mission gets transferred to your next, so it is a good idea to use it wisely, often relying on salvage ships to steal enemy ships over building your own. Space combat is done on a fully 3D plane, where ships can easily move in all 3 axis, which at the time was revolutionary.

Gearbox did an amazing job in remastering this great gem, the graphics is amazing, while keeping the story and the music intact the game is truly perfect now. They made some UI and control changes but in the end it results in a smoother gameplay.

There are a few minor bugs such as a sound issue with ship engines when too many of them are moving at once, and the tutorial being slightly broken (you get asked to press okay to continue to the next segment but the tutorial continues on as if you already pressed it), however these are minor gripes and does nothing to ruin this wonderful title.

My ratings are as follows:
Graphics 8
Music 10
Story 10
Gameplay 9

reviewText:
Homeworld. It used to be considered one of best RTS's ever made set in space combat. After it was remastered it still is one of best RTS's ever created. I have never played original games, bought the game during recent steam sale. Money well spent. The game is just amazing. Homeworld 1 Remastered feels like one is playing Battlestar Galactica (2003-2009). On the other hand Homeworld 2 Remastered is more of war story while keeping up mysticism of 1st game.
First thing I can tell you now the game is not easy, You need to learn its controls and how it works otherwise you will keep loosing. When you learn ropes of the game its extremely pleasant to play and most importantly enemy will still outnumber you, i.e. in 2nd game the enemy will have 10 battlecruisers while you have a cap allowing you to build 2 bc's. Quite unfair considering their firepower but frigates are perfect cannon fodder for that :P

Story of two games is just amazing, both cause you feel rush and despair. Graphics in comparison to original game imporved really well fitting modern standards (including 4k if u can handle it). The soundtrack is purely amazing and is used in appropriate moments to affect us as players when necessary. Adagio for Strings choral by Samuel Barber is actually one of most beautiful songs ever created in our history. Yes, its used in best moments in the Homeworld 1 Remastered! Other soundtrack is also amazing but this very specific song is purest masterpiece of all,

Gameplay. It's great. Cant say anything more. Combat is balanced, fights are challanging and its easy to loose if you're not using the thing in ur head at all. This is defiently not casual game where you hop in and immediately become a god in it (like designers of modern games do nowadays with games is just wrong!) Nothing beats sight of full scale fleet vs fleet combat. Bloody yet stunning.

Homeworld Remastered Collection is great offer. You get 4 games (2 original + 2 remastered games) and if you are considering to buy it, do not hesitate. You will not regret spending your money on the game (sale or normally). Right now I feel like a thief for buying on summer sale. This game is worth way more than I've paid for it.
I feel like I want to keep returning to the game to play it over and over. It is that good, great replayability value and satisfaction from it.

To sum things up:

+ Nicely improved graphics that fits modern standards
+ Masterpiece soundtrack (and im quite hard to impress with music)
+ Great Gameplay and replayability value
+ Great story that actually makes you feel desperate, in rush
+ Want more!
+ Not casual...

- ... which for some console peasants will be a bad thing.
- some bugs
- not well explained graphic settings in the video settings

reviewText:
When I was around 14 or so, I remember heading to a friend's house where he and his brothers had a number of gaming PCs set up, all networked in and online. We would play Everquest, Counterstrike, and a number of other games into the wee hours of the morning. There was one game there that stood out to me; that game was Homeworld.

Homeworld is an amazing game. A journey through both an amazing, emotional story and wonderful gameplay. The score is driving, the visuals are breathtaking, and the whole experience is awesome.

If you played this game at original release, then I'm sure you remember the first time loading it up, hearing Samuel Barber's Angus Dei and seeing the Mothership. I know you can recall the emotion felt when the fleet returns to Kharak only to find it burning under an enemy assault. Countless memories flood forth from the mere mention of this cult jewel. Why it wasn't more popular at the time, I will never know.

A friend and I would play this title over Gameranger. We did for a good many years, actually. We would always joke about them doing an updated version of the game (if not a HW 3)...well, those jokes have become a reality. An awesome reality.

If you're a fan of the original, or curious about this game...I say go for it. It is worth every penny.

If you are new to the game, I envy you....you're about to take an amazing journey on your way home.

reviewText:
In 1999 I played a game that would forever impress me
When I opened the box I was presented with a beautiful manual/lore book full of information and background for the game I was playing.

It was beautiful

Then I loaded the game up.
I was stunned by the gorgeousness of the graphics
I marvelled at how times had come along so much that this piece of art was now in my possession
When I played the game the intricacies of the strategy and the challenge of keeping your fleet in one piece and seeing it grow, remembering that old ion array frigate in the last mission that you acquired in the third mission, the epic story as you fought for the right to regain your homeworld and I thought it couldn’t get any better.

I was wrong

A year later Cataclysm was released, a standalone expansion from the original, it used the same engine but it was altered in a way that changed the rules, following a story set 15 years after landfall on the homeworld, you follow a family of miners who uncover a dark secret and a parasitic virus and you must race to stop it. Again it expanded on the visuals, tactics and story, again I thought it could not get better, and again I was wrong…

Homeworld 2 was released in 2003, and with it a rewritten engine, stunning visuals that reminded me of the opening scene from revenge of the sith, and a slightly retconned but no less epic story.
100 years after reclaiming your homeworld, the old enemy have arisen under a new leader. Using the artefact of an ancient super powerful hyperspace engine, But you have one too, and there are legends of a third. To reclaim your homeworld once again, you must liberate the second core, find the third and unite the cores to end the threat once and for all.

Can it get better?

Yes, Homeworld remastered is all of these games (with the exception of cataclysm, which I hope they add at some point) with updated engines and even better stunning hi definition visuals. It’s an epic experience. If you have played the original and loved them, buy it. If you’re a fan of epic sci fi, buy it. If you like strategy games, buy it.

Just buy it, go on click add to cart and put your money where it belongs.

reviewText:
The homeworld Remasterd collection is without a doubt an amazing piece of work.
All the controls are the same (if you can remember back that far, 15 years IS a long time).

The graphics, which were amazing 15 years ago, are even better in this remastered version. Even the cut-scenes have been updated and even look better. Everything has been completely updated including the sounds.

Some things were added to the game, such as fleet grouping controls.
For example:
Selecting 10 vessels and groupling them as fleet 1 then selecting 5 of those vessles and making them group 2, all vessels in the fleet remain group one as well as the 5 that are also group 2.
This was something that wasn't included in the original Homeworld when it first came out...at least as far as I can remember...lol...it has been 15 years.

Gearbox also updated the play screen with fleet info, mission recall data, and que update that was included in (the lost homeworld game) Cataclysm as well as Homeworld 2. So some helpful bits have been added to make the game what it should have been 15 years ago, but Gearbox hasn't altered the game away from what it was, which was awesome in its own state.

Even the tutorials are still helpful in playing the game. Even if you've never heard of the game and decided to buy it, playing a tutorial in homeworld will definitely give you all the info needed for basic game play. This also trickles into Homeworld 2 as they have the same controls ;-).

As far as I can tell, everything that was part of the original is included in the remastered version. Since I haven't played through completely, I can't tell if the original song The Ladder- by YES was included as the end song. Its a little over 9 minutes long I think LOL, so you can't miss it.

All in all, the game remains one the THE BEST RTS games in the genre. Definitely a must have...especially since the original PC game has a very good chance of not working on the newer and faster PC's, not to mention with the updated graphics cards.

I've only seen a handful of games that have been remastered, but only a couple of this age. Gearbox has definitely done a great job with The Homeworld Remastered Collection.

Definitely buy this game.

reviewText:
In the infinite majesty of space, cruelty and beauty can be found in equal measure. A race brought to the very brink of destruction through the violation of a treaty signed millenia ago, left marooned in space clinging to a technology salvaged from ancient ancestors and a single guiding star. Home.

This sets the stage for one of the greatest space strategy games of all time, Homeworld. A game that has rarely been aspired to since, and a game filled with ideas that even to this day are rarely even touched upon. Only now a few daring indie developers dare brave the complexities that represent true three dimensional space combat and even then they have yet to come even close to what Homeworld achieved. It was lightning in a bottle, a cult classic synthesised from a pace that was stately enough to appreciate the sheer majesty that the game inspired with its' sweeping scale, a soundtrack that was borne of classical tones and distant melancholy, and a story that took you on a true campaign, where your units would carry over from mission to mission, along with your resource pool.

These are all concepts that in most current campaigns are oft ignored, set aside for flashy Michael Bay style set pieces and much shallower, more simplistic stories. Homeworld told stories of shades of grey, of culture, of alien races with diverse backgrounds and lore, of imperialism, of a nebula home to a technologically advanced enclave that sought refuge and peace within the sanctity of drifting ghostlike threads.

Homeworld Remastered is a restoration of that premise, Gearbox have carefully and considerately taken the Homeworld 2 interface (the better one) and the source assets, placed them in a more modern, more capable and more mod friendly engine, and then carefully brought the game up to current generation standards, with lighting, depth of field, better framerates, higher resolutions, better texturing, cleaned up the sound work, the whole lot. The result quite literally is Homeworld as viewed through the rose tinted glasses of memory"

reviewText:
Gearbox has (re)created a beautiful-looking space strategy game that will impress those new to the series but leave oldschool Homeworld fans bitterly dissapointed. If you're looking for some fun multiplayer action you'll love this game but if you want to revisit the classic Homeworld campaign I cannot recommend it unless there's a serious effort by the devs to address the many problems in the launch version. Read below for detailed comments.

THE GOOD:

- Absolutely gorgeous graphics. Everything looks very nice and with some minor tweaking plays smoothly even on my     not-so-good laptop.

- The original artstyle in the cinematics has been faithfully recreated and, again, it all looks very nice.

- Excellent, engaging story in HW1:R, same as the 1999 classic.

- Good voice acting and music bring the experience to life.

- Multiplayer is, despite some balance issues between the HW1 and HW2 races, simply a blast to play.


THE BAD:

- The game uses a modified HW2 engine which does not seem to work very well with the HW1 campaign/units. I'm not sure how many of the problems listed below are due to engine limitations and how many can be patched in, if someone more knowlegeable about HW modding can chip in on this I'll edit the review accordingly.

- Strike craft formations/tactics simply do not work for the HW1 units. Strike craft will assume a formation when ordered to but after combat is joined they will attack seemingly random targets on their own flight paths regardless of tactics settings used, making concentrating fire to specific targets impossible and leading to a lot of losses.

- The HW1 remastered campaign in general lacks polish. Missing/bugged mission triggers, wonky AI behaviour (resource collectors in particular will randomly stop harvesting after dropping off their loads), ship engine sound effects persisting after zooming in and then out on some units, sensor manager sometimes just deciding to stop working altogether, repair corvettes apparently not working at all and simply atrocious difficulty scaling.  Expect to reload a lot to get through some missions.

- The dynamic difficulty scaling seems way out of whack for the campaign. The HW1 campaign now uses the (almost universally despised) dynamic difficulty scaling system originally introduced by HW2. In a nutshell, the enemies you'll face are generated depending on your fleet composition at the start of a mission. Some people like this idea, some don't. Regardless of how one feels about it, the system clearly has not been playtested enough as the seeming lack of hard caps on enemy numbers will lead to some unwinnable fights for players who like to build up their fleet. For example, capturing a good number of enemy corvettes in mission 2 will cause an overwhelming number of enemies to spawn in the following mission, leading to a game over before the introductory cutscenes are even finished.

CONCLUSION: I'm really torn on this but I'll have to go with a no recommendation until the flawed port of the HW1 campaign and strike craft mechanics are addressed. If you're a returning HW1 veteran definately hold off on this until the game is (hopefully) patched and/or modded to make the experience closer to the original. On the other hand those new to the series will no doubt appreciate the engaging story of the campaign. The fun multiplayer can also help a lot so consider what you want of the game and take this review as it is.

reviewText:
Well... As it stands right now they made HW2 okay but completely ruined HW1 in every way shape and form.

Formations in the REAL Homeworld don't work properly, they don't stay in proper formation. Capital ships can't maneuver worth beans, Destroyers are no longer the ultimate utility ship of the fleet anymore. They were designed in HW1 to keep pace with and LEAD the frigate lines. Now they're slow, lumbering beasts that just ♥♥♥♥ me off.

Frigates are now made of wet paper bags and fighters are slow and unmaneuverable, meaning point defenses and even heavier weapons could destroy them. Corvettes are now pointless to build. Basically you just build fighters bombers and super-capitals only and they are all that is worth building.

The GUI is NOTHING like the original Homeworld which let you have a very clean experience which didn't block anything out. If you didn't need to see the GUI at that moment, it wasn't there. One of the things that made Homeworld loveable was that it assumed you were intelligent.

Singleplayer's adaptive difficulty from HW1 is now gone from what I can tell and it is pathetically easy for an experienced HW Vet. I had little trouble in the first few missions, which was dissappointing to say the least.

Fuel consumption no longer exists for fighters which means that when I eventually reach the Garden of Kadesh I can expect to be utterly massacred by the Kadeshi. This makes the Support Frigate a useless item. Honestly, why have them anymore at all?! The whole ballance is gone by removing fuel consumption, barring the other things they've utterly mucked up.

I'm happy that they thought it worth the effort to do a remastered edition but they sacrificed the original Homeworld ENTIRELY in order to satisfy the Homeworld 2 players. The thing is... There is a LOT more Homeworld 1 fans that stayed true and bought this than there were Homeworld 2 fans (at least if my group of friends is any indication).

Gearbox... Hear us! Fix your rather glaring mistakes! Homeworld 1 should have been the priority... Especially since THAT is the one that won Game of the Year in 1999. And lets be honest... It had some pretty TALL competition back then for that title. It didn't just win Strategy Game of the Year, it won overall Game of the Year....

Frankly I want a refund because this wasn't true to the Homeworld legacy at all... As far as I am concerned the basic models for the ships are the same and then cut-scenes are the same. The rest is garbage.

reviewText:
Experience so far with HW1:R
1. Played tutorial to brush up on game. Computer would proceed to next step without me hitting the proceed button. Fixed that by enabling subtitles. Oddly, received achievement for finishing HW2:R tutorials.
2. Had to restart mission 3 three times as my salvage frigates were on enemy fighter but would not bring it back to mothership. If I would not already own and have played the originals, would never have known this was a mission advancement bug.
3. Destroyed enemy carrier at end of mission 4, game went to mission failed, yet computer was telling me I completed it and the hyperspace button was showing behind the mission failed window. Did entire mission again and it worked.
4. Stopped playing at this point, as I didn't want to waste time playing and hitting another mission advancement bug. Will definately keep going, but knowing that is a possibility is a turn off.

Is it fun? Yes. Does it look good? Yes. Does it(and by that I mean HW1:R) feel like it wasn't fully tested and rushed? Yes.
I bought two copies. One for me and one for my son. We both had same issues on two different computers.

Should you buy? Up to you. I got my codes off Amazon for less than Steam's preorder pricing, after release, and after I read great reviews. Would I buy again? Knowing what I know now, I would wait for it to go on sale. But that's just me. Hopefully they will fix the bugs.

That being said, as I said before, it IS fun, but knowing I might hit an advancement bug ruins some of that enjoyment. Graphic bugs, etc., I can accept, but not something that keeps the game from moving forward.

Edit: Finished mission 5 without a glitch, although it seems much easier than the original. Just basically spammed and sent ships out to the enemy. No real tactics involved other than that.

reviewText:
I didn't play the originals like many reviewers have and have just completed the H1:R campaign, havent even touched the second one yet. I will post a review of HW2:R seperately.

I will start off by saying I only leave reviews in cases of extreme, has to be so good or so bad to illicit a review. This game is definitely not the latter. I have played many RTS games through my life and very few were able to tell such a tale as well  as this one has. The journey was enthralling and gripping and has so many interesting events along the way. The combat is great and while the scenery leaves room for improvemnet it is hardly missed when your fleet engages the enemy and capital ships trade blows while fighters and corvettes dance through a three dimensional space. I enjoyed every mission many of which had different obstacles and goals to keep you interested and sometimes force you to use very different approaches, spamming a ton of two units wont get you far like many RTS out there. A must buy for anyone who enjoys RTS or space games, seriously get it.


11/10 would make the journey again.

reviewText:
There is a single reason i cannot reccomend this game. Dynamic difficulty. What is that?

You have ships of total power 5, the next encounter has enemy ships of 7 power. You have total power 7? The encounter will be of power 9. You have 10 power? You go against enemy power 13. And so on. You always deal with a supreme force. A fleet equal to yours and somewhat better to counter the human brain superiority against CPU AI.

The main supportive idea behind that is that you cannot focus on build a massive fleet and win by numbers. You have to use 'real strategy' and 'real tactics' to win. At least that is what they majority of fans are saying.

Well i disagree. And the reason is simple. Firstly, i beat the game and without any save-load-try again stuff. Not a big deal, most players can do, if not they need some retries and that is all. Really, since when load and retry is a deep strategy and tactic?!?!

On top of that, why build a lot of ships? The game does not count your stored resources for adjusting difficulty. You go with few ships, face few ships, build a few more and keep going. If that is strategy and tactic i am Napoleon.

Not to mention the salvage corvette thing. Two corvette class ships can disable and salvage a frigate (and larger classes) but 2 combet class corvettes cannot take down a frigate. The salvage class ships would make sence if they salvage disabled or heavy damaged ships. This looks like a cheat to me and not a tactic.

To make a long story short, do not build many ships, have 2-4-6 and so on salvage corvs, build few ships after the encounter has spawned and you are good for the entire game. Do not use your resources to build ships in advance before you hyperspace. 'To be prepared' obviously is not this game's motto. 'Play dead' is more like it.

Nice experience from a view, i do not rememeber any other RTS punishing the hard prepared folks.

reviewText:
I bought this when it was in the Autumn sale, hoping for a better, more up-to-date experience than the original. Both the remastered and original versions are included. The graphics are indeed very good but then it goes downhill...

The audio (music) is very similar but some of the voices have been altered - I prefer the originals. On my original PC this pushed the limits performance-wise so I was pleased when I could now push everything up to 11 - and it all worked well (only occasional crashes).

But what has utterly ruined it is the interface. It's clunky, some of the key combinations dont work when they are supposed to, the key bindings have changed from the original game - and some of them cant be re-assigned.

Coupled with the lack of *Military (the default) ship formation for setting up squadrons, this makes it sooo hard to play and keep track of everything. I gave up after a couple of hours and got my money back (thanks to the Steam refund policy).

I'f you've never played Homeworld you may like it and you would accept it as it is, not knowing any better. Unfortunately if you remember the original as fondly as I do then you are likely to be dissapointed.

*You can get the Military formation by docking then re-launching all your ships immediately - but its a faff.

reviewText:
Seeing how this game's price has completely crashed during the Autumn sale, I figured I would add in my own two cents.

My dad introduced me to the original Homeworld when I was about 7 years old. That was about 13 years ago, and even after playing every single spaceship-related game I could get my hands on, I never found anything which went into quite as much depth with story, lore and gameplay as Homeworld.

Now believe me I was just as hyped as the next person when Homeworld: Remastered was announced - in fact my dad would tell you I nearly brought the ceiling down with my enthusiasm, especially when I discovered that it was Gearbox, well-known for producing the Borderlands series (which I am also a HUGE fan of) was in charge of spearheading the project and bringing it to us. When it came out I didn't really see much of the shtick it got for myself, but after taking more time to play it since I have unearthed its little issues that the original game lacks. The good thing about this though is that you get the original games bundled with the remastered versions, so if the Remastered versions' issues become a bit much for you, you can easily revert to them to take a break. Now I'll give a breakdown of my own personal pros and cons, make of them what you will!


PROS -

- The game is, of course, remastered - graphically speaking, the game is stunning - the lighting is perfection, the backgrounds of matches are perfect, and the various ships look beautiful with their new models - the frigates even have moving turrets, which I think was lacking in the original game. There is not a single flaw in the graphical side of the remastering, at least in my opinion.

- The campaigns for both games have remained pretty much untouched - but a new GUI allows for easier interaction with the game world and better control over what comes into your mothership and what leaves it.

- The ship upgrade system located under the research section allows players to upgrade the stats of their various ships, including damage, defense, health and occasionally speed. They can also be used to teach some ships new abilities. In the campaign mode you are limited to when you get these upgrades however as many of them tie into the story in various ways.

- The addition of mod support, although often shaky at times, does allow for the addition of custom races, ship logos, maps and I think even gameplay modes. Some of these mods can even be used in online play, which I think is fantastic.

- While the original Homeworld soundtrack has been left untouched and rightly so, the Homeworld 2 soundtrack recieved a remastering which has drastically improved the sound of its music, which was in the original game something of a partial failure (Some of the songs sounded shoddy or rushed for example but these issues have been fixed in the remastered soundtrack).

- The lore is extensive and beautiful for this game, but many people are often unaware of this without having access to the original Homeworld manual, which was a hand-me-down from my dad which I still read regularly. The details contained within the manual are available on the Homeworld wikia for those who are curious about learning the extensive background of this universe, as much of it isn't actually mentioned in-game or at least not in a way that some people would really understand or remember.

CONS -

- The original game didn't have any bugs or glitches that I can remember. This one has a great deal of them, however - simple things like unresponsive ships, the occasional crash and other silly things you could perhaps expect from a game, but still annoying due to how flawless the original felt.

- Mods often deselect themselves and don't load after being used in-game for only one match. Sometimes mods don't work at all or crash the game, which is appearntly a very common occurrence.

- The patches do help but often don't fix the really important issues, such as common issues with multiplayer and mods.

- Some gameplay aspects that people really enjoyed were for some reason removed, such as the ability to Salvage (why they even bothered leaving the poor little Salvage Corvette in the game is beyond me, considering that in the main storyline of Homeworld 1 they are practically useless after the 3rd chapter now and just sit there collecting dust until destroyed by enemies) and also the need to refuel ships. While I actually think of this as a good thing, there have been complaints about it and I can imagine that for some people it must have taken some of the survivability element away from them.

- Although I have no solid proof at this time, I've heard that there are serious issues with multiplayer on occasion. Multiplayer also allows you to play as any of the races from the two games, which in some cases could be a little unfair as the races from Homeworld 2 have packs of Interceptors rather than one Interceptor per construction (just an example, I know there are others too), as well as having better ships overall.

Overall I'd say this game is worth its sale price, but maybe is only worth its true retail price to the hardcore fans who will appreciate it and can ignore its flaws indefinitely.

Also another tip: If you are one of the owners of the original CD of the game which came with the soundtrack on CD, you don't need to buy the Homeworld 1 Remastered Soundtrack. It's literally the same music. If your CD is still around or in good condition, use that instead and save your money :P However the Homeworld 2 Remastered Soundtrack is different from the original as stated above and is very much worth the money in my opinion.

reviewText:
The exiles have returned. It's been 16 years since we first left Kharak but now we make the journey once again.

Research reports new technologies to aid us:
+ Highly detailed visuals of our fleet and the enemy fleet will increase targetting.
+ Those that completed the journey before will be able to relive the best once again.
+ Recon tells us that enemy numbers will be based on the size of our fleet. (Missions now scale based on fleet size so that amassing a huge fleet early on won't make the game too easy later)
+ AI Tactician Software that allows one to match the fleets of ole with the fleets of new. (You can play HW1 / HW2 sides in multiplayer).

The Mothership is taking light damage...
- Some bugs in the programming may need to be worked out.
- Strikecraft and corvettes are overally suboptimal currently. Requesting research upgrades.
- Rookie pilots are unable to stand in formation correctly.
- Ship Captains are unable to use stances accurately.
- Asteroids.....

Assessment: While the Mothership was unable to complete all of its subsystems, given time it will be repaired.

reviewText:
I'm only a few hours in, but wow.

I never played the originals, despite being 31 years old and owning an extensive collection of games in all genres. Somehow, this series completely passed me by.

After two solid hours of playing the remastered version of the first game, I am in love. The UI and controls are intuitive and smart, and the game systems are rock solid. To anyone in my situation contemplating whether or not this is worth the money, I'd say go for it.

What truly makes this stand out to me is that it feels like a space opera. The story has grabbed me right from the get-go, and the immersion is like nothing I've ever experienced before. What really does it, in my view, is that with each new mission/objective, you keep your fleet and resources throughout the campaign. I don't know of another RTS game which does this anywhere near as well.

The game feels like a journey home, and reminds me of the (later) 2006 series, Battlestar Galactica. It's fantastically written, the soundtrack is incredible and the world feels gigantic.

Probably the best <£30 game I have bought in years.

Very, very highly recommended.

reviewText:
Amazing remastering. They could have updated only what was needed, which they did (you get the classics too).

But now you get update models, textures, backgrounds and UI. All running silky smooth. Audio quality is so much clearer and the cutscenes sublime.

This is now the gold standard of HD+ Remastering. I can't wait for Homeworld Shipbreakers and eventually, Homeworld 3.

reviewText:
Homeworld is a very niche game. If you like space battles and want to see the absolute best there is on offer from any game to be frank, you'd want this game.

The actual game itself here is a bit of a rough diamond. The gameplay involves a spherical map where you can move your ships in basically any direction up or down as well as in the horizontal plane, which in theory would open up tactics and such. In practice, its mostly a minor annoyance, for all it is technically impressive. It is tactically useless, for the most part. You could the vast scope of the map, particularly its height to hide, but hiding is never practical to be honest - unless you're gimping yourself against the AI and carefully setting it up,  you're not making a battlestar galactica style comeback if you get smashed early on.

The gameplay boils down to who has the best fleet and the best target acquisition.  You select everything, and send it into the fray all at the same time and then click the enemy to death. The aesthetics are really down to your taste but personally I hate the design of the HW2 ships pretty much across the board while the Kushan in HW1 are in the same boat as looking awful (fighters look like flying ice cream tubs)  the Taidann look far more convincing and the only ships I really enjoy looking at. The NPC races in the campaign look pretty atmospheric and fitting as well.

The HW1 campaign is in the vein of traditional RTS games, where there are some missions with some absurd challenge that you need to try multiple times, which is a double edged sword but I think generally it works. It makes the game more interesting and about learning rather than turtling and then sending the biggest possible fleet at something. If you want the best experience, I'd never reload a save, (but you will spend hours waiting for resources to collect or fleets to build) and the reason for this is that with the gimmicky missions there's generally a key lesson that you'll learn or figure out on the first go, so the second attempt is really easy. In one mission, you'll find your small craft will almost always get wiped out due to overwhelming firepower. The solution is to just dock them in your carrier/mothership.

Units carry over between missions. In the original game, this meant that if you spent hours waiting to collect all resources before moving on, you'd have a significant advantage in the next mission. In remastered, you get all resources all over the map at the start of the next mission. There's a clear reason why Gearbox has made this change but it makes the last few levels ♥♥♥♥ easy.

The last 2-3 missions stop being unique like this and essentially become move and attack fests where you move your death fleet across the map and slowly destroy everything. The enemy fleets don't scale well to your own superfleet that is carried between missions and just about the most challenging large fleet action is in one later mission  where you effectively have to leave a small force of  capital ships behind to defend your mothership from flankers while you win the mission.

HW2's campaign is better designed such that a few of these problems are less significant or non-existent. The difficulty is more consistent throughout unlike in the first game where the difficulty is far worse at the beginning of the campaign. The story elements in both games aren't anything overwhelmingly special but are pretty decent and get the job done.

In terms of the remastered elements, Gearbox didn't totally screw it up, but they did do a pretty ♥♥♥♥ poor job. If, like me, you have a fairly new AMD card with the latest drivers, you can't play either of the classic games as they will instantly CTD on launch. This issue has been around for several months and hasn't been fixed, and likely won't ever be fixed.  One graphical issue I've seen involves ships becoming completely see-through. This has been around since release and hasn't been fixed definitively, though there is a solution - its as overwhelming basic as changing the properties on the HW shortcut, so its pretty pathetic that its still around. In terms of campaign bugs, some missions or objectives fail to complete and particularly the infamous asteroid mission has artificial difficulty stemming from the stupidity of the pathfinding AI literally flying into rocks, and the long pause between being able to target split up asteroids.

One of the main reasons you may want to get it is because of the brilliant mods made for classic that are being ported to remastered (though extremely slowly - none of the major ones have yet made the transition) that literally serve to make Homeworld a platform for simulating any space warfare universe imaginable. There's Freespace 2, Halo, BSG, Star Wars, Star Trek, even Wing Commander amongst other things.


I'd say the game is still worth getting on sale, even despite all these faults. There is a net gain in enjoyment from playing this game, though be warned if you have an AMD card.

I'd give the game about a 7/10 on a scale where 5 is *the* average game, and not an average game".

reviewText:
The originals, fantastic loved it to bits and I have always revered it as one of the best games of its time. But unfortunately Gearbox rehash does not do it justice.

The graphics are nice but all in all not much of an improvement to be honest not with the current technology (Congrats on improving some textures including the odd explosion).

The other thing that really gets me is that they have butchered a great useable interface with something that seems unfinished. Which is functionality lacking drastically, seemingly clunky and cumbersome.

Not just functionality though it seems entire original functions are missing, for instance one example (of many) a simple toggling ship overlays in map overview which very useful in the original not only helped manage your fleet but also added aesthetic, I really coudl go on but I don't want to waste my life here.

Grouping seem hit and miss to having a tendency to disappear on saves in single player, formations don't stick docking procedures don't stay docked.

For a graphics overhaul they could have at least got it right.

Even a little imagination with achievements could have gone along way.

Shame to say although the nostalgia trip was a nice one to go down, it feels yet again gearbox have released another game that is not even scraping half-arsed anymore and broken.

I think the only thing that may hold this game a float and any reason I may come back to it, is the workshop for multiplayer with my friends.

reviewText:
Well what can I say about this that hasn't already been said but really it is something that is out of the world. For I remember playing the Classic Homeworld when it first came out and seeing it redone was just plain awesome. The new graphics and such are great. Seeing the old Mothership 01 redone was great. Seeing the old Classic ships redone was great. While I have yet to finish the Campaigns of either of the games I do admit I am looking forword to playing them in the near future for it shall be a treat.

That said, there are some issues that I have with the game:
No Time Compression therefore those long after mission resource gathering bits are quite boring.
I actually liked the old Classic Manager Screens but that is not really a large issue and I can get use to it in time I am just a fan of the old screens.
Scuttle can be used with one click of the hotkey or the UI Button on screen. I have lost a couple ships this way by missclicking which included the Mothership which was quite a shock for I was in the middle of a battle and suddenly I scuttled the Mothership. I want the old double-click scuttle back so this doesn't happen.
The Campaign After-Mission Hyperspace UI Button is in the freaking middle of the screen. I would like to have it somewhere else in the UI so I can do final after-mission stuff like finishing harvesting and construction or researh before I head on to the next mission.
No Raider Attack Mission, which if I rememeber right was supposed to be included with the Remastered Campaign but apparently I don't see it.
Anyhow, this game is great coming back from the grave and I shall see about going on to finish the Campaigns in the day ahead. Thanks gearbox for bringing back these great games. Now get to work on Homeworld 3 or the Shipbreakers game.

EDIT:

Alright I am ♥♥♥♥♥♥! I just realized a couple things while playing the game which really made me get a bit upset. First of all in HW1 Remastered you cannot fully capture ships. You can grab them with your Salvage Corvettes and take them back to the Mothership. HOWEVER, they do not come back out under your control. Instead it looks like you get RUs in exchange. This is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t! The one major fun part of the original HW1 game was going out and capturing enemy ships before using them against your enemies. Now you changed it! What...the...Heck!

Gah! If that isn't enough the damn Formations are wacked up. I tried to put my Fighters and Corvettes into a Sphere Formation to Guard a Salvage Corvette in Mission Two like I normally do when I am playing the original game. However the escortings craft don't even do a sphere around the darn Corvette like they are supposed too! I almost lost my Salvage Corvette because the damn escorts were too busy dogfighting enemy craft then protecting my poor Salvage Corvette. Then there is the Repair Corvette which in the original game you could have it guarding a couple ships where it can heal its charges in the thick of battle. However this can only be used on one ship. What in the world is going on here! Gah!!

Thanks alot Gearbox!!

reviewText:
I just spent the last six hours ( thought it was three ) playing this game.

I say, they have recreated this game in probably the best way I think could ever be done.
I played a lot of Homeworld, and none of it online.  I spent a lot of time in the campaign, and in botmatches.  I even tried playing with the modding for a bit.  It was amazing.
And now we have this.
Coming from only having played Homeworld Remastered, not 2, or the Classics, or the multiplayer, I can say it is... exactly how it was.
It even played performance-wise the same way!  I have a 550 Ti, and this this thing managed to pull a reliable 30 fps through 80% of the game, but there was a bit of dip in combat, so it was just like old times on my crappy Celeron PC back in the ages.

Now, the remastered version uses the Homeworld 2 engine, so if you only ever played Homeworld 1, you might be a little bit confused.  I think the changes to the engine are a nice touch.  I spent quite a lot of time admiring that all the ships look exactly the same, but just... better.  The small details are REALLY nice, and I haven't even begun to touch them yet.  I have to work tomorrow. ...maybe...
For instance, when the Turanic Raiders are encountered, focus on one of corvettes' missiles. You'll see.

Anyway, there's any number of tangents I can go on, but basically, this game lives up to the hype machine that was created for it.  I only got to mission 5, and I already don't reget buying this as a pre-order.  I wouldn't regret buying it again for a different computer at full price.  If you loved either Homeworld game, but especially both of them, buy this.
It will not be a game you regret buying.
I look forward to fragging some of you in multiplayer.  :)


Cons:  Still no Cataclysm.

reviewText:
Homewolrd was on of those games where you either loved it or hated it.

From my personal experience with the game, I really love it, had to really drag myself away from it at 2am this morning to et some rest for work later today.

The game being re-mastered has managed to keep is atmosphere and environment, the story really pulls you in. Multitasking and designating your squads to defend carriers as well sending other squads to deal with the enemy carriers while you continuously harvest more resources and research. There is so much going on.

The ui is slightly different, personally I liked the old UI but this new UI all it takes is getting used to.

The PVP part of the game is where I think it will really make or break the game for the future. Personally I like the hyperdrive element brings in so many strategies like a decoy attack to the front of an enemy base while your team mate hyperdrives behind the enemy base and nukes.

This game is awesome, if your in to RTS even as a solo player I would defo recommended it, the skirmishes against the CPU can be quite fun as well if you don’t like PVP.

reviewText:
I have only played a few skirmish matches so take this with a grain of salt, especially with the numerous bugs that are apparently still in the game. Gearbox have a bit of a ♥♥♥♥ track record in my book so I was sceptical.

Well the game looks and feels great and is an absolute nostalgic blast. Once you hear the Ion beams and the delightfully nonchalant battle chatter (a welcome distraction from the try-too-hard cliché military gruff stuff we are used to nowadays) you feel right at home. Controls still hold up, though I would've wished a middle mouse button camera panning. It's a nice throwback to when RTS wasn't about unit spam or superhuman micro capabilities.

The visuals are neat. Seing HW1 in this fidelity is a treat, HW2 also looks nicer but the leap isn't that big comparatively. Ship damage is still just pre-rendered 2d sprites but even those got increased resolutions. FOV is also cool but really gimmicky. Overall performance is decent, could be better though seeing as this isn't exactly cream of the crop visually despite all enhancements. This is still a 15 year old engine at its heart.

Negatives are that the AI wasn't improved and is still kind of dumb. They'll get stomped even if they keep up with your economy. Also the UI scaling doesn't affect the ever obnoxiously large sidebar.

Overall a recommended buy, for the ability to play this on current systems alone.

reviewText:
Homeworld remastered is exactly that, the original homeworld with slightly improved wrapping.
While this is generally a good thing and if you liked the originals (like I did, a lot) then buying this makes sense. You will get the same game with updated visuals and sounds.

However there are some negatives, most of them are just missed opportunities, but they still count as negatives:
- Models are extremely low poly for a 2015 game
- objects (mostly ships) could be much more detailed
- Textures look low res as well
- effects look 5-6 year old at least (like engine glow as such)
- voices are a bit more bland then the original, they seem more like script read than a person saying them.

In general it is an improvement on the original for sure, but the original was revolutionary for its time, this is passable at best for 2015

reviewText:
Rose tinted glasses is a risk with the 'golden oldies'. Homeworld was a fantastic game back in the day, and to get that out of the way immediately: It still is.

So, I recommend the game. But it is worth knowing ahead of buying that it is not a perfect game. It looks like a 2015 game. The game doesn't play like it, though. The campaign has a great story, but it has an unforgiving side and as your fleet stays with you throughout the game, it can be punishing or require loading. In that regard it's quite 'oldschool'. That is not necessarily bad - or good - but is something you should be aware of.

As for the multiplayer, there's some region limiting that can be worked around, but you don't get more epic space battles than multiplayer Homeworld. Nothing even compares.

I note that a lot mention bugs. I haven't run into any, for what it's worth.

reviewText:
I wholly recommend this to anyone new to the Homeworld series, hoping to play Homeworld 2 with a new coat of paint, or just want something different from the normal RTS we have nowadays. It is a wonderful remaster that has brought this timeless classic back into modern gaming. It has a wonderful campaign that is a moving space opera that urges you to keep playing. Do keep in mind that as of this review, the multiplayer is in BETA. I would buy this for the campaign rather than the multiplayer, but it is indeed worth the price.

However if you played Homeworld 1 and you're buying this for a remastered version of the original, they have changed some things (HW2 UI, no fuel management, scaled enemies based on your force in the campaign, no Yes song in the ending) but it is still an extremely enjoyable experience. Even if you don't like the remaster, you still get the originals in this collection to play to your hearts content. The originals packed in this collection are exactly the same as the ones you would buy in the box 15 years ago.

Thank you Gearbox from the bottom of my heart for making this happen.

reviewText:
I never played the originals (back then) but i heard so much about them, tried to play the 1999 version and i simply couldnt, when i heard they were making a remake i followed the news until release when i patiently waited for a good discount before jumping in, my experiences are as follows:

Homeworld 1 Remastered

The game
Play the tutorial, dont jump in recklessly. 3D movement is iffy, formations are useless-ish. The game looks beautiful and the intro missions really encourage you to continue on your quest. The balance of this game is off, leaning towards a mass of ion cannon frigates, destroyers and heavy cruisers. Hard counters are not hard enough, specially when facing a mass of fighters in one of the missions or several ion cannon frigates in another mission. It boils down to can i outgun you before you destroy me?" with ion cannon frigates. The automatic balance worked very strangely during my run
date: giving me two very easy final missions. The AI can be wonky ni your favor or against you
hoursPlayed: some will follow a single probe to infinity and beyond or sometime you may be relentlessly attacked
voteText:
also movement in this game and the next takes time and theres no time compression. All in all if you played old time RTS like command and conquer (the first one) you should be fine with the interface and controls.

Story and sound
The story has a good start a sluggish middle chapter and a fantastic resolution even thou the final battle itself is not that epic
helpfulPercent: i was enthralled at the start almost quit playing at mission 10 when a game breaking bug ocurred but pushed on to Mission 11 where stuff happens and it was one wild ride to the end. The voice acting is monotonous as it was on the first original game
votesHelpful:
i feel some of the "feels" were lost when no emotions are shown by the different voice actors with the exception of the mothership which is a "machine". Finally the soundtrack that really grabbed me in the entire game was the Homeworld version of Adagio for Strings that really enhances the scenes it is played on.

Conclusion for Homeworld 1 Remastered
Bear with the mechanics

reviewText:
*Gregorian Chants fill the expanse of space as the light of a distant star filters through the red gas clouds of the local nebula*

For those of you who played Homeworld or Homeworld 2...you know why you should buy this.

For those of you who have never had the priveledge...this game is still considered by many experts of the RTS genre to be the defining RTS experience.  One of the most polished, best story-driven RTS games ever made, AND the sequel.

It is a space saga...an epic journey of a people to reclaim their homeworld...and then...an aeon later, to flee said homeworld before destruction rains down upon them.

It is...the most beautiful RTS I have ever seen.   Even before the remaster, I would've said so.  Now...it is updated in every way one could hope for, without ANY changes to the core mechanics.

The story is the same, but the voice acting is all-new, from the same actors who voiced the original.  The graphics are modernized, and the game feels...fresh.  It feels as it should;  essentially unchanged, but better than ever before!

I recommend this game to anyone who seriously wishes to give the RTS genre a genuine try.   If you don't like this, you probably won't like many other RTS games. On the other hand; If you like RTS games, this will likely be the jewel of your collection.

reviewText:
Bottom Line:  I’ve enjoyed this from release.

I've had this since release, and I originally would not have recommended it.  It should have been released as early access. However, the developer is constantly releasing patches and has fixed many of the issues raised in old reviews.
I have only played multiplayer (mainly because I’m waiting for them to fix HW1 ship behavior for the campaign), but updates have focused mostly on campaign fixes thus far.

Two major topics I want to address:

Multiplayer is still unbalanced, but the forums have regular updates about progress and active discussion with developers.  I expect multiplayer balance to gain more focus, since many of the game stopping bugs are fixed. Multiplayer is playable, and it’s come a long way from hoping 2 of 6 people make it in game without crashing.

reviewText:
As someone who has never played any of the original Homeworld games, I can't comment on the changes made and if they are bad or good. That said, this game is amazing!

Stunning models and graphics, great story and cut-scenes, and easy to learn controls are just the tip of the iceberg.  The skirmish mode lets you play with huge fleets in large scale wars which is a blast. The great mods being uploaded to the Steam Workshop only enhance that experience.

While some people, probably most of the veteran players, dislike that both games in the collection (HW1 and HW2) are built in the HW2 engine, as a newcomer to Homeworld, I felt it made the whole experience more intuitive.  The transition between the two games was easy as it all felt the same. Two seperate engines might has disrupted the flow as players who just got accustomed to HW1's engine would now have to figure out the small changes made in HW2 and force a change in their mindset.

All in all, an amazing, amazing game. I highly recommend!

Can't wait for Homeworld 3! :)

reviewText:
*Gregorian Chants fill the expanse of space as the light of a distant star filters through the red gas clouds of the local nebula*

For those of you who played Homeworld or Homeworld 2...you know why you should buy this.

For those of you who have never had the priveledge...this game is still considered by many experts of the RTS genre to be the defining RTS experience.  One of the most polished, best story-driven RTS games ever made, AND the sequel.

It is a space saga...an epic journey of a people to reclaim their homeworld...and then...an aeon later, to flee said homeworld before destruction rains down upon them.

It is...the most beautiful RTS I have ever seen.   Even before the remaster, I would've said so.  Now...it is updated in every way one could hope for, without ANY changes to the core mechanics.

The story is the same, but the voice acting is all-new, from the same actors who voiced the original.  The graphics are modernized, and the game feels...fresh.  It feels as it should;  essentially unchanged, but better than ever before!

I recommend this game to anyone who seriously wishes to give the RTS genre a genuine try.   If you don't like this, you probably won't like many other RTS games. On the other hand; If you like RTS games, this will likely be the jewel of your collection.

reviewText:
Well 16 hours through and campaign complete.

Admittedly without formations things were a little more difficult, but not so much that it's unpassable (I just passed it!)  I played the original when it came out, and pre-ordered here. I can't say that without these features that this game isn't HomeWorld.  The story, the voice acting, the music, the gameplay, it's still all top notch.   This is what really made Homeworld.

So I have to naysay the naysayers.   You still get the originals if you need to be that purist.  Maybe they'll patch it, but the game was very releasable at the point it is today.  It's still a fun game that can invoke emotion in you.

For folks who have never played...

Homeworld was created during a time 3D on a computer was still in its infancy.  There was a lot of games made at the time that were duds, and a few greats like Homeworld.    The game did well enough to warrant 2 sequels and a port to Mac.

You play the part of a exiled race who discovers warp technology.  As soon as you fire up your engines, those that exiled you come and destroy the only home you had, the desert world they left you stranded on 4000 years earlier.   As the fleet, you are responsible for the last remaining survivors of your planet.  There is no turning back.

As you progress through the game, you research new ships, each with unique abilities.  Levels are laid out in a way where you have to put every newly learned ability to use, almost like a Puzzle.

If you've ever watched The Angry Video Game Nerd talk about how perfect Mega Man X is for teaching you how to play, through gameplay, Homeworlds puzzles are a bit like that.

One peice of advice I can give... Save.. Save often.  It sucks to have spent an hour trying to get through a level, only to die right before the end.

reviewText:
Probably one of the best, if not THE best HD remaster of a game to date. Sure, games have advanced a bit since, but this game is a classic, and is in all aspects a work of art. Both sight and sound. The remaster does several things.

1 - It makes the game something you can get without a cdrom.

2 - It vastly improves the games models, textures, and effects (it was visually stunning in its day, and now its even more so).

3 - It resampled all the games audio to be much more high quality

4 - Vastly improved (and scaleable) UI.

5 - Both homeworld and homeworld 2 in one package

6 - New multiplayer functionality.

For me, it was worth it just to be able to play through the 2 games stories again, on a new high end system, and have the game look and perform amazingly. This game is an experience, one that hasnt really been duplicated since it was released. New game devs could learn a lot from it, but in the mean time, im glad to get to play this series again.

reviewText:
My partner received this game and has played it thoroughly, but she did not get a chance to finish it.  I can tell you, for a fact, that she loved the original game and was overjoyed when she had the opportunity to play this.

The graphics are superb, and she loved every minute that she played of it.

Here is the review that she asked me to copy for the game.

Pros:  The graphics- the graphics will melt your eyeballs directly into your head.  The brightness of the sun as it pans into your viewscreen would turn any vampire into dust immediately.  They are THAT realistic.

Gameplay- Combat happens quickly, and it cannot be paused.  You can restart any time that you wish from a quick saved game, but who wants to do that?  Death and destruction is part of the galaxy, folks, and you will see plenty of it.

Audio- Your neighbors will insist that the Apocolypse has arrived, centered in your living room.  Even at the lowest volume, if you have downstairs neighbors then they will be pounding on their ceiling for you to turn it down.  The explosions rattled my teeth and killed my pet skunk.  Not before he sprayed his gunk everywhere, though.

Battlefield size- The best game that I ever played that comes close to this is Sins of a Solar Empire.  If you've played that, imagine each battlefield to be as large as an ultra large galaxy map in its entirety.  Battlefields are in true 4D space, and combat happens from up, down, sideways, behind you, diagonally, etc.  TRUE 4D.  The only way it could be better would be if you could actually feel the heat from the explosions, but then your couch would be melted and you would be dead.  I suppose we should stick with 4D.

Cons: Length.  Too short.  I spent (as many hours as it showed I played) and didn't even come close to finishing it, but I knew how many missions there were.  I made it to (check my achievement history) before I couldn't play anymore, and it is the high point of my last half year.  Knowing that the end of the game was coming mad me sad, and I wanted to cry.  Then why did I say it's too short?  Because it will come to an end, eventually.

I wholeheartedly endorse this game, and this is the largest review that I've ever written for any game in my library.  That means a lot.


************************

That ends her review, and I agree.  I watched her play, and was mesmerized by the storyline and the action.  I never played the game before, so it was all new to me.  This game is not going to be a waste of your time or money, I promise.

reviewText:
Updated:  Make sure to read the bottom edit.
The countless hours I spent on this series as a youngster were some of my fondest memories of gaming. I completed the campaign for Homeworld at least 3 times, HW2 twice, and Cataclysm (somewhat non-canon, but still good) a few times as well. I've only reached the fifth mission in this HW1 Remastered campaign, but it appears Gearbox did the series proud.

It's beautiful without compromising the original art, the updated interface is mostly an improvement (I'm not crazy about the different hotkeys) and the sound updates are amazing. There are nuances to the sounds that I never picked up in all the time I used to play the game.

One change that had me absolutely giddy is that it's now (much more) possible for salvage frigates to capture Turanic Raider ships. I always wanted a fleet of Missile Corvettes, and now it's possible to nab them all!

Overall, I'm blown away by this remaster. I'm overjoyed at how well it's done. If you never played the Homeworld games and you're an RTS or space fan, do yourself a favor and play this game, now.

Edit: There are some serious issues with the game that I hope will be fixed soon. These are:

1) Harvesting resources in HW1R is buggy, and requires babysitting and constantly reassigning the harvesters. They will stop harvesting, even when there are additional resources 30 seconds away.

2) Strike Craft Formations and Tactics are useless and broken: Moving HW1 content to the HW2 engine clearly broke these, and they are critical to making strike craft useful. As they are right now, you will constantly lose all your strike craft due to the unit AI's inability to utilize tactics and formations. It forces you to just boat captured Assault Frigate swarms and other Frigate/Capital ships instead. This is a major and disappointing issue, and possibly the worst of the list.

reviewText:
This game is everything a Homeworld faithful could have hoped for! After a decade, it is so refreshing to play one of the greatest games ever made with a fresh coat of paint. The story is still as evocative as ever (better than any trash AAA game currently out there,) the strategy is as complex as you wish to make it, and the graphics...the originals still look good, but holy cow the remasters are gorgeous! The dialogue was wonderfully redone, staying true to the originals whilst adding some depth and emotion. The game isn't a breeze to beat, but it's not a 4X either. It's just enough challenge to make you claw back for more!

The only potential things I would have done differently:

Bring squadrons to the original, it's tough to micromanage so many ships with only 10 groups
Add more ship types (such as from the complex mods) to give greater depth, especially in HW2
Having the 4 races be playable is great, but it'd be nice to have a mode with playable Keepers and Progenitors too

There is embedded mod support in the main menu so I imagine once modders get their eager hands on the code and start releasing stuff it'll be a lot easier to incorporate them into the game. This is great, since I was never able to make the Complex mods work on my Windows 8 machine.

Looking forward to several more years of this game!

reviewText:
Oh my god.  Homeworld's back.  I never thought I'd see this day.  I don't know how many hours I put into the originals.

So far, not many bugs on release other than a couple crashes.  If you crash, lower the texture quality a notch.  Even at 2048 texture size, it's beautiful

To top it off, this is NOT one of those games that looks better through nostalgia glasses.  Between all the engine improvements, HD textures, etc, it's BETTER.

I remember playing HW1 when I was a kid and getting destroyed.  15 years later, with an adult mind, it feels like a different game.  I know how to manage resources better, I know the strengths and weaknesses of ships better, and try to organize my fleet instead of throwing units against the enemy hoping to get a kill.

EVEN IF YOU DON'T LIKE RTS, GIVE THIS GAME A TRY.  It looks like another overcomplicated space RTS, but it's really not.  It's complicated in its own ways, but very easy to learn the basic tactics and rock-paper-scissor mechanics between all the different ships.

This isn't like other RTSs.  It's very easy to pick up and play, hard to master against real players, but the selling point is the beautiful campaigns of HW1 and 2.  Not to mention the massive battles, with fighters zipping everywhere with their glowing contrails, and massive capital ships hammering at each other with cannons and ion beems.

Good lord, it's been a long time.  It's more beautiful than I remember; with the Remastered engine, it's more than just a polished up HW2 engine.  Check out any comparison videos.

This game has gotten *BETTER* with time.  How many series/remakes can say that?

reviewText:
Woke up this morning to Homeworld remasters fully installed and ready to go. Forgot to feed animals and children and wife woke up and decided to pick a fight (true story).

Wife is now at the in-laws for a few days and I can play my beloved old game that made me the nerd I am today.

In all honesty the remake is amazing. Graphics and overview changes have made this game incredibly better without changing the heart and soul of what Homeworld truly is. A masterpice of gaming history with a storyline without rival.

Do yourself a once in a lifetime favour and purchase this game and watch your family, life and job disappear into endless space with a huge smile on your face.
